The cot made a sound when he moved that was louder than the sound he required the town to give up, and the irony would have amused him if he liked feeling anything. He had not liked the way the boy had tapped. He had not liked the way his own hand had written the words Don’t make noise with the care of a child copying from a chalkboard; that had been a mistake to do it himself and not make the machine carry the message. He had not liked that a rope had burned a wrist and would show. He had not liked that Claire had stepped on his cord because that was a housewife’s trick and he did not want to be vulnerable to the habits of kitchens. He had not liked that the corner had refused to be a door. He said to his own chest, tomorrow, and the chest did not promise the way a mouth might, it beat, it insisted, it kept the time of his making.

He had known hunger as a boy that had nothing to do with food and everything to do with the noise adults made at each other. He had learned to sleep under a table with a hand over his own ear as if he could press the world out of his head. He had found in the photographs that there is a way to excise only the part of the face that betrays the rest. He had told himself he was an artist of reduction. He had told himself art was not cruel because art is beautiful and, like most men who tell themselves neat lies often enough, he had found ways to keep evidence away from that sentence. He did not sleep and the arrhythmic crickets in the weeds beyond the tin wall made him ache because they had charmed the night into believing they had a right to it. He would fix that. He had a line to finish. He had found the top lip on a map without letting the map know he was reading it.

Kline put a pin into the paper with a force that made him wish he didn’t care about maps. The circle had its mouth; the line was a mouth; what needed closing was obvious now in a way nothing had been yesterday. There was the overpass near the service road that had been poured with a pride that didn’t match its budget and always sounded tired. There was the water tower’s ladder where no one had fixed the missing rung because everybody had memorized it. There was, most obvious and therefore least likely, the courthouse steps where speeches go to be empty and high school seniors go to find echoes they can pretend are agreement. He didn’t think it would be any of those because he had learned that the man loved edges that were also private. He looked at the skating rink again on his paper and at the warehouse with the tin letters and at the rivoli and at the threshold of the gym and then he put his finger on a place he had not loved as a boy, where the drainage culvert goes under the road at King Road and opens its iron mouth into the ditch. It was private and public; it was mouth and edge; it was a sentence and a correction. He told two cars to go there and a man with an orange vest to stand on the bank and pretend to be city and a woman who could run faster than men thought to be in the shade. He did not tell Claire because he could not ask her again, not tonight, and because he knew without knowing that she would be where edges met whether he asked or not.

Claire wrote until the lamp made a halo on her desk that did not belong to any saint. She made sentences and broke them on purpose and then made them again. She wrote, clap wrong, and she wrote, call him by the name he was given in the kitchen of a rented house, and she wrote, teach your mouth to be a door with a lock you own. She thought about the boy’s key tapping and wrote, tap even if you do not know the code, and then crossed it out because she did not want to issue commandments and because every commandment invites a man to police it. She wrote instead, be heard crooked. She wrote, if the shape is a mouth you must refuse to be its lips. The printer made its domestic noise and she loved it like a clock in a house where someone old is sleeping.

The morning slipped over the town with a look of mischief as if to say you thought you knew afternoon? Watch this. Someone rang the church bell at ten not on the hour but because he wanted to, because he kept the key and there was nothing in the by-laws to stop him. A woman set a metronome on her porch rail and wound it and then knocked it off with the back of her finger so it swung like it was being teased. The teenagers met behind the bowling alley and tuned the wrong way and one of them remembered an uncle’s CB radio and wired it to a car battery and discovered by accident that if he set it on a metal trash can, the can talked back. These were stupid things and holy ones. The town smelled like late peaches and oil.

At the culvert, the city man In the orange vest kept up a cheerful lie with his clipboard as if he counted everything and could therefore control anything. The woman in the shade twisted the strap of her sandals around her fingers and practiced not humming. The deputies in the cars pretended to be bored in the way men pretend to be brave. It was the kind of place you could close your eyes and still see because it had been in more small boy adventures than any state test could measure. The water came out and made a sound that the man at Harv’s shop would call white and the rest of them would call day. A crawfish had built the kind of cathedral that only crawfish build and had decorated it with what it had.

He came because of course he did. He came because even men who think they choose their own places live in towns that have been choosing for them since they could walk. He came in the long step of someone who has learned how to use his length to look like he is in a hurry when he is not. He came with a new thing on his shoulder, a bag that had once been a mailbag with leather softened by hands, the kind of thing that makes a person look like a story as soon as they put it on. He set the bag down in the mouth of the culvert and the culvert accepted it like a communion and the air changed the way it does when rain goes from idea to rule. He had a hand on the strap when the woman stepped out of shade and said his name because saying nothing would have been a betrayal of her own throat. “Alessandro,” she said, and it made the culvert drop a note and pick up a new one.

He did not turn toward her. He turned toward the orange vest because the vest was a color that had been making demands his entire life and because he had never liked colors that did not occur in nature. He lifted the bag again and then he did a thing that no one expected and which, if it had been written down in a police report, would have looked like a lie. He took from his pocket the cardboard circle on a stick he had left on Claire’s porch and held it up to the mouth of the culvert and framed it. He framed the mouth within the mouth and smiled, and it was a terrifyingly ordinary smile, the kind a man gives when he has remembered a joke he never got and feels proud for pretending. He set the bag down like a gift. The woman stepped backward because instinct is older than training and because the water had told her, in its way, to get taller ground. The deputies moved forward with their hands like waiters carrying trays of certainty.

The sound that bag made when it woke was a different animal. It did not push the air so much as attract the least part of it and stitch it to its neighbor and then their neighbor until the room around the culvert learned a hum that felt like being pulled through a sieve. The culvert amplified it and turned it into a suggestion that knees could make agreements with chairs. The woman grabbed the edge of the fence and let the chain bite her skin into diamonds and it kept her where she meant to stay and not where the sound would have preferred her to be. The city man made a face like he tasted cinnamon where he had expected salt. The water tried to add its own voice and discovered it had been written out of the measure and added itself anyway. It is difficult to mic a creek; he had not planned for that and for one moment he loved creek for the wrong reason.

Claire did not run again. She walked fast and felt her breath as a unit that needed to be carried precious and upright and not spilled. She came to the culvert corner and did not see him first, she saw the bag in the mouth and knew it had an appetite. She went not for the bag but for the signs that said, in their old paint, City Property, because sometimes you have to interrupt a sentence before it becomes law. She swung the sign on its single good bolt and it squealed into a sound the bag could not predict because rust is an improviser. The deputies put their hands flat on the hood of their car and made a drum. The orange vest clapped the way children clap when they have been asked to show a stranger their talents and their talents are still their own. It looked silly. Someone in a house above the bank turned on a vacuum cleaner because that is what she had, and the sound bent the trees on a frequency that made the bag hiccup.

Al had come for the last line and he was getting a chorus he did not want. He did the thing that he had done at the gym and which had failed there and which he believed would not fail here because men with plans always think a new room will love them. He lifted the camera. He lifted it because when he had nothing his hands could make sense of, he could always make a square. He framed Claire because that was the square he hated and wanted. He clicked and the square woke and the chemistry began to guess at what it would be and she lifted her kazoo and blew one long wrong note into the mouth of the culvert and made one child on a school bus a mile away look up because he could feel that someone was letting the air be wrong on purpose. The picture came out and he shook it not because it needed it but because men shake things when they are impatient and like to see liquid learn. He looked at it because he could not help it; he had taught himself to love the reveal more than the result. It showed a mouth; it showed a mouth; it showed something that might have been hers if she had been someone else. He had not caught her. He had caught an idea badly made, and it made him frown like a man who has stepped on a nail he meant to save for later.

Kline had been coming up from the under of the culvert with a pace like a man who had learned to be sure on wet concrete and at the moment the man’s attention went to the square he put his hand on the bag and slid it backward the way you pull a cake from an oven prematurely and it collapsed in on the sound with such a small meekness that he wanted, briefly, to spare it. The bag whined and then lied about not knowing how to whine. The culvert was itself again and the water rushed, embarrassed by the interruption but unpunished. The city man with the vest did the brave stupid thing and kicked the bag into the shallow and watched the river make a joke of electricity and hoped for the best. It sparked like a small Fourth of July being ashamed of itself. The woman in sandals laughed and hated that she laughed and laughed anyway because her body had kept the receipt for delight and presented it at the wrong counter.

Al looked at Kline then with attention and it was like being stared at by a building. There was no malice in it, only the weight of his disappointment resting on the nearest table. He put the camera back into its pillowcase because he had learned that some acts are cheapened by the air. He stepped back and it should have been a mistake because there were men who would step forward if given that permission, but that was not what this town did with permission anymore. He turned not to the road this time, not to the ditches he loved, but to the cut through the trees where deer made their own law, and he moved through it without bending a branch because courtesy was something he knew when it had leaves on.

There were a dozen reports that night of a man that tall walking that slow along the edges of other people’s yards, and most of them were wrong and a few were true and all of them were proof that a town, once taught to see, will see even when it does not want to. Leah’s phone lit again and she did not answer and she sat with it in her lap and said a student’s name out loud and the phone went quiet and she had not known it would. Harv picked a sliver of solder out of his thumb and put it on his desk as if it might grow into a flower and closed his eyes and thought of his wife’s mouth not as a picture but as the first place their older son had smiled. Kline took his map down and put it back up and put it down again because he could not bear to see the shape of the line and could not bear not to. He put a tack in the culvert and the tack pressed through paper into cork with a sound that the town would have recognized now if it had been standing exactly where he was, which it was, in a way.

Claire went home by the long way because the air had gotten into her hair in a way that made going home too quickly feel like a lie. She passed the alley with the graffiti and someone had added beneath it in smaller hand: AND WE ARE THE HUSH WE PICK, and she wanted to argue with the unknown hand and wanted also to hold it. Her porch had a letter on it and it was not a letter because it had no envelope and it was not a postcard because it held no picture; it was a square like the ones on his line but it was blank and she hated that and loved it because blank is a better threat than a promise sometimes. On the back, in the neat boyish hand that did not marry the body she knew from the ditch, were four words: TOMORROW WE WILL FINISH. The we was still there and still wrong and still seductive because we is how songs begin. She brought the square inside and put it on the floor under the table where the legs had a nick in one and her mother had kept a book under it to cancel the wobble. She did not put a book under it now. She let the table wobble. She let it.

Morning came with a headache and a blessing. The boy from the fence woke up in a hospital room that had been painted the impossible blue of a particular hour in a particular Mississippi spring and asked without words with his mouth for his mother and she was there and he was given a cup with a lid he did not need and an ice chip and a permission slip to be loud later. The paper ran a headline that said LIGHT STAYS ON and no one liked it and everyone kept it. The men who fix things rolled up their sleeves with a little extra civility because someone had asked them, not ordered them, to take care. The school band announced a concert at noon in the square with the caveat that people would be asked to clap like they did not know what clapping was, and parents bought earplugs and did not tell their children it was in case, they said it was for the fun of the thing.

Kline met Claire on the courthouse steps because some habits make sense even when they are bad, and because you can see farther and less from up there than anywhere else. He had a paper in his pocket like a teenager. He had written the names of the places he thought were left that would satisfy a man who needed to complete a shape and could not stand to be told no by corners. He handed it to her and she folded it without looking and put it in her jacket like a person who understands spells and hates them. Neither of them brought up the we in the note because words have spines and you can feel them in your throat if you say them and neither of them had time for that kind of bones.

“Do you think he sleeps,” Kline said finally, not because it mattered and because it mattered more than it should.

“Not in a way that helps him,” she said. “Not in the way that makes a man remember he belongs to a body.”

“You’re not afraid enough,” he said, and there was admiration in it and a complaint and a hand he offered without offering.

“I’m afraid like a drawer that’s stuck,” she said. “I’m afraid in a way that stays useful when I need plates.”

He laughed and then stopped and then laughed again because he loved being made to say stupid things that were true. “You coming to the square at noon,” he said, aiming to sound casual and landing where he always did when he asked her to do a thing she shouldn’t have to do: earnest and a little ashamed.

“I’d rather be where a map thinks it ends,” she said, and they both looked at the culvert in their heads and the water tower and the skate rink and the bit of road that had never decided whether it was a street, a lane, or a place.

He gave her the look he gave people who chose to do the thing he was going to have to ask them to do anyway. “Don’t be brave,” he said, and it landed on the step between them with a sound like a coin and like a seed.

She went anyway. She walked to the road that was not a street or a place and stood in a noon that had found a cloud and was pleased with itself for it. There were few people there, which is a different kind of courage than a square full of band. The train was an hour off and she had never been so aware of timetables that were made by men. She held the blank square he had left her and bent it once and unbent it so it would remember being changed. She thought about the first sentence she wrote after the gym and about the cruelty of fresh pages and about mercy with teeth. She thought about his grandmother or the woman who had pinned his life to a line and how he had learned to love clean things and how that love had ruined him.

He came like weather that has checked the clock. He came without a machine because he was confident that humans are machines too and he could press them. He held the camera like a dovecote and it was foolish how elegant it made him look. He stopped in the middle of the lane and the lane did not mind it, lanes are worse than roads that way. He set his eyes on her mouth and she felt it the way a woman feels the sun on the back of her neck in a dress that cost more than her paycheck really allowed. She tasted plastic because her teeth reminded her of the kazoo and she had not brought it because she didn’t think jokes would help. She had brought the one thing that would make his hand tremble. She had brought his name.

“Alessandro,” she said, and for the first time he winced and didn’t hide it. He lifted the camera and she lifted the square he had brought her as if she were in on his trick and put it between her mouth and his lens and framed herself and he hated it more than he had hated anything because he had not given the permission for that framing and because she had made him a we with a cardboard circle and he was a man who had sworn that word off.

The shutter clicked and the picture came out and the emulsion began to be itself. He did not look. He saw himself, in his head, in a room with clothespins and he hated that he could hear wind through the slats. He saw his father’s hand putting nails in a jar and calling it sorting and he despised the jar for its accuracy. He lowered the camera and he might have said a word then. He might have said no. He might have said mine. He might have said please. He closed his mouth around all of those words like a man closing his hand around a bee, and whether he meant to save it or kill it was not clear even to him.

A patrol car turned at the far end of the lane too sharp and too soon and the driver cursed himself for stopping a poem with an engine. The horn he laid on was the wrong sound at the right moment and it tore the day in half and someone on a porch who had thought to be useless and had not been took a lid off a pot and dropped it on concrete and it skittered in a language the bag in the culvert would have hated. The picture in his hand revealed itself with a small shiver, and he looked because you look—and what stared back was not a mouth. It was the cardboard ring with her fingers in focus on both sides, the cut edge of her defiance, the thing he had meant to make a tool turned into a mirror. He had caught his own shape on the inner edges where the circle framed him wrong. Behind the ring, blurred but deliberate, her mouth was open, not pretty, not clean, speaking, a mid-sound that could not be read as yes or no. He had collected the un-collectable, and the rage that rose was old and unoriginal and he despised that about it most.

He took a step that took too long and that was enough. Kline’s hand found the part of his arm you can hold a man by without breaking him, and that was all it took to make the camera tilt and the square drop, and the wind, which had been sleepy, woke and took the picture a foot. Claire stepped on it not because she wanted to own it but because some things must be stopped before they join and become story. He wrenched and Kline let go because letting go sometimes keeps a man in a room better than grip does, and the next moment was no one’s and everyone’s, and if you asked ten people later what they had seen you would get ten true things.

He did not run and he did not stay and he did something between, a shuffling grace that got him out of the middle and to an edge, and the edge made a choice for him because he had taught edges to make choices. He vanished into the narrow green where the ditch makes a lie of asphalt. Kline did not chase because he had learned something about himself that morning, and it was that he loved his life and the count of it more than he loved arrests you boast about in bars. He would get him. He believed this with the kind of faith he wished he had for other things.

Claire stood with her shoe on a picture of herself, a self-outside-of-self, and looked down at the circle, at the cut dull gray of cardboard, at her own fingers blurred, at the idea of a mouth that had been trying not to become an idea. She lifted her foot and took the square with two fingers the way you take a spider you would rather not kill. She slipped it into her pocket with the paper where she had written WE ARE THE NOISE WE KEEP in her own hand. She felt ridiculous and alive the way you do when you have been lucky and have not yet paid for it. She walked back toward the square because the band would be starting and because she wanted to hear the wrong clapping echo off the courthouse and make the history inside it roll over and cough.

They had put folding chairs out as if the town would be polite and then abandoned them as if the town remembered itself. Leah stood on a milk crate and pointed at nothing and made meaning anyway. The trumpet player who ran the tire shop blew a note that had swallowed three others on the way in and arrived fat and satisfied. Children clapped and threw away the count like a bad toy and found that their hands could make and unmake a room. Kline stood at the back with the faces he loved and the faces he had made and the faces he did not know yet, and he let them wash him in ugly, beautiful, useful noise until his eyes stung and his law loosened and tightened at once.

In the shed that smelled like sugar and trouble, a string of Polaroids stirred because air moves more in rooms that have been argued with. One clothespin, old wood with a spring that had seen better, gave up. A picture fell and landed at an angle and leaned against the leg of the table where he had placed the welders and the cutters. It was a mouth, it was three mouths, it was an error he had kept because even neatness allows for trophies of failure sometimes. It looked, in the slant, like a canyon. He was not there to see it because he was at the edge of a different room deciding how much longer he could be a man who labeled his own boxes, and somewhere in him the word we rose again, stubborn and reasonable, and he hated it and knew he would use it when he meant I, and the thought made him strong and it made him tired and the town, which had learned its shape and would go on learning, made its noise and kept it.Chapter 9

Morning came on like a brass band that had stayed out late and still found its tune by muscle memory. The square wore last night’s laughter like a shawl. Grocery carts rang against one another as if to demonstrate the difference between an accident and a rhythm. Down King Road, a woman hung damp sheets with clothespins that had belonged to her grandmother, and each pin clicked with a tiny, private vote for ordinary. The town had the look of a place that had been frightened into remembering that it liked to be alive.

Claire woke with the ghost of a headache and the stub of an argument at the back of her tongue. The blank square from his note lay on her kitchen table where she had left it, and the corner she had bent and unbent held its crease like a healed bone. Her house had new sounds now—bells she had hung on the inside of the front door that knocked together when the AC kicked on, a child’s wind-up music box a neighbor had left with a note that said for luck, the anxious thrum of a fish tank someone had abandoned at the curb that she had taken in and filled with water even though there were no fish. She had made her house rude on purpose. When she stepped into the hall, her heel caught the edge of a wooden spoon she had dropped there the night before, a booby trap that was also an invitation, and the clatter made her laugh in a way closest to a cough.

She put on coffee and left it to burn while she wrote down a thought she did not trust herself to hold in her head during the half-minute it would take to pour. The dip in the lip, she wrote, and underlined it. The lipstick in the church photograph had marked the bow of the upper lip—the little ravine some mouths have between nose and Cupid’s mouth—that had been his drawn line. His map, she saw now as if someone had traced it with grease pencil, had included that dip. You finish a mouth with a cleft. You give it definition. You make it a mouth in more than outline. The water tower had a vertical line painted down its fat belly where the city had been measuring rust the year she graduated from high school and had never painted over. The catwalk halfway up made the thin line cross the round and make a feature on a face. If you were a man who made your map out of an anatomy you hated and needed, that was where you would go to be finished.

She called Kline to tell him a thing he had already circled in his head and he did not sound annoyed to hear his own thought back at him. He sounded relieved that thoughts could be communal without making him smaller. “We already put eyes there,” he said, “but they can’t live there. They’ll scare him wrong or they’ll make it into a scene and he wants a scene. I sent a boy to sit on the hill like he’s sketching and I sent Mrs. Landrum to walk her dog and I asked the mayor to develop a desire to count rivets, but that’s cover and no net. He’ll come in weather. He likes the air to do the heavy part. We got a storm late afternoon if the forecast isn’t bragging. You know how thunder lets gentlemen do things they don’t want witnesses for.”

“He’ll use it,” she said. “He’ll make it part of the sentence he’s writing. He’ll borrow the bass and give it the verb. You need to make the sky stutter.”

“I don’t own a sky,” he said, rueful the way men get when they admit the limits of their badge.

“You know people with sheet metal,” she said. “Ask the shop to lay out boards and hammers and tell folks to make their own thunder wrong. Ask the church to ring the bell on the up-beat and then forget the beat. Tell the band kids to bring pots. If he uses the sky, you make it answer itself in a way that messes with his grammar.”

“You terrifying me with how pretty that sounds,” he said. “But I hear the part I need.”

After he hung up, she stood at the window and watched the neighbor’s pecan tree drop last year’s bad shells in a steady confession. The sky had the tight, oily look of a day that will get violent at dusk and forgive itself by dawn. She called Leah without planning to and got her on the first ring. Leah was in the gym with a handful of teachers and a custodian who had never in his life been paid enough to love the sound of a floor polisher. “We’re teaching clapping like we had to teach it to foreign exchange students once,” Leah said with odd cheer. “We’re inventing mistakes and awarding prizes. I have never felt more useful and more foolish and I’ve been a teacher in a state with a legislature.”

“After school, go home,” Claire said, hating herself for the boss in her voice and needing it. “Go home and make noise in your kitchen. If a friend comes by, let them. That thing he brings—if he brings it here—will like the neat of this room too much. Make it messy before he gets the chance. Teach it what a home does when it has to be a weather vane.”

Leah laughed, then swallowed the laugh in that involuntary way of late fear, and then released it again because the room needed it. “My father would say you’re a woman with a broom telling a storm where to move,” she said. “My father would be right and I love him more for it most days.”

The boy from the fence asked to see Claire and she walked to the hospital with the printout of the words she had made that people had taped to windows and church doors as if paper could keep out a doctrine. He was sitting up in bed with a plastic bracelet on his wrist that made him look like someone’s experiment and he had a drawing pad. He had drawn the giant wrong in a way that made it better than right. He had drawn him as a shadow with holes where eyes should be and one of the holes had a moth in it. He showed her the picture and the picture made something behind her sternum go soft and old.

“You counted wrong,” she said, and he looked alarmed until she smiled. “You counted wrong in the way that saves a person,” she added. “Keep doing that.”

He bit his lower lip the way children do when they want to memorize their own faces. “He moved quiet,” he said. “He looked like when the moon goes behind a cloud and then decides not to. I wanted to say his name. I couldn’t think of a name for him.”

“Names are earned,” she said. “You don’t owe him one.”

Harv called mid-morning with his mouth full of the language of bolts. “He pulled these cones from a particular kind of sound bar,” he said. “Not the cheap ones. The ones with red cloth on the ends that folks buy because they like to pretend their winter is theater. There’s only one place around here that still sells them because everybody else went for the Bluetooth candy. That outfit off the bypass that makes you sign for everything like a mortgage. The manager there is a man who keeps a list of who owes him. He will remember a man like a lightning rod. He will remember the way his elbows moved. He will remember whether he paid cash careful or cash sloppy.”

Kline sent a deputy in his Sunday shirt to be nice about it and the manager remembered better than nice. He remembered a man with hands like a stovetop choosing the box with no barcode on it like some men choose seats on a bus. He remembered the way the man stood on the square of mat near the cash register and made the chime not ring, a trick that should not be possible. He remembered a name not because the man had said it but because he had said what he wasn’t. “Not Alan,” he had said, when the manager asked if he wanted a warranty. “Not that.” He had smiled the way a man smiles when someone calls him handsome on the street. “Al,” he had allowed. “Just Al.” The manager gave the deputy the footage from the camera over the counter and apologized for the picture quality as if shame could make pixels grow teeth.

The state boys arrived in a car that looked like a bar of soap sharpened at the ends. They shook hands the way men who know their hands will be held in lieu of thanks shake hands. They used words like tactical and psychological operations and one of them had a degree in a thing he had never properly been allowed to love. He walked the shed and breathed the air and surprised Claire by being mournful about the Polaroids. “There’s a tenderness in this cruelty,” he said, more to the air than to her. “That makes it worse, or better,” he added, and then took himself out of the room so he would not say something else foolish and true.

By noon, the sun had decided to preen. Heat hammered the sidewalks. The square filled with the band kids and the worst rhythm section in the county. A man from the city rolled a fifty-gallon drum to the courthouse steps and a boy with a stick made it talk and then sing and then complain. Claire stood in the back with her paper folded to a talisman and watched people she loved elect to be unlovely for an hour. It was marvelous. It was terrible. It was effective. It got under the skin of the day and made it itch.

Clouds muscular as men rose in the southwest. Kline pointed at the water tower with his chin in that way his father’s generation had turned into art. “We do not go up,” he said to the pair of deputies who were younger than his daughter would have been if his life had gone another way. “Not in daylight. Not when we can see our own hands. If I can see you, he can see you. He’s got the patience to wait until light lies. We can put a man at the base who looks like nobody. We can put a car a block out that looks like a car belonging to a man who doesn’t like to go home for supper on time. That’s what we can do.”

“What do we do with the wind,” one of the deputies said, and because it was a joke, they all laughed as if they had told it.

They did what they could with wind. They asked a roofing company to lean sheets of tin against sawhorses with cinderblocks under the open ends so they would speak in a small voice when the storm slouched through. They asked a man who liked to rebuild mufflers to pretend for an hour that he didn’t. They asked the woman with the church key to ring wrong. They asked the train dispatcher if the next engineer could hold the horn longer than company likes and he said he could not say he said yes and Kline said he would not say thank you, then they looked at each other in relief and guilt the way men do who are making exceptions together.

Claire went home and put on her mother’s shoes, which were ugly and solid and meant for standing a long time in a kitchen and she loved them for being honest about their purposes. She filled a canvas bag with things she would have mocked last year—a pot lid, a rolled-up stretch of chain, a bundle of old keys on a ring the size of a palm, a child’s tambourine with three of its jingles missing. She added a coil of clothesline and a handful of clothespins out of habit and superstition. She put the blank square in the inside pocket of her jacket with the corner filed toward her like a tooth and tried to decide if she was being brave or if she was building furniture out of fear and calling it useful. She compromised and called it a bench. Benches do not win wars, but they let people sit and decide to keep going.

At three, the first lick of thunder laid its tongue along the far hills. The air went greener than a living thing should be. The town found places it remembered hiding as children and then didn’t go to them. That was the point. They stood on porches and left doors open and put radios on stations nobody liked and turned them up. They banged hammer handles on the undersides of tables. They loved their errors in public. Down by the tower, Mrs. Landrum let her dog pee on the same post three times in three directions and told it it was a genius and the dog believed her and wagged its tail faster than the day required.

He came when the third thunder spoke, because the third is the telling one, and because he believed in sequences more than he believed in God. He brought a canvas bag he had found in a pawnshop with a faded name stenciled on it that he had half scraped free; it had belonged to a man who’d traveled for a little team that wanted to be a big team and the ghost of that ambition pleased him. Inside the bag were a ring of speakers nipple-small and rude, an array the size of a clock that had no time, a coil of wire that he had lifted from behind a print shop’s broken plotter. He carried a length of EMT conduit cut with a dull blade to wedge the bag where he would need it and he carried a short-handled hammer because hammers have souls and pronounce themselves in ways other tools do not. He had a roll of tape that had been applied to other things before and took it personally, and a camera because he was himself and would always be until something interrupted him.

The tower was a town in miniature. It had habits and rules and a ladder everyone knew to be missing a rung and solved with a step wider than comfort. He moved like he had measured it in childhood and someone from a second-floor window said later that he made the ladder look like a cane for a man too proud to limp. He made no noise his own bag didn’t generate. Rain began like static and then like accusation. He climbed into it because rain quiets footfalls and also because his skin had never made peace with water and he liked to punish it as if it had disobeyed him by being what everything else was made of. He got to the catwalk and let his weight teach it his name.

On the ground, a deputy with a baseball cap pulled low looked up and kept looking up until it hurt. He spoke into his shoulder and the shoulder told the next shoulder and pretty soon shoulders all over the county knew the man had gone up and what town do you know that is good at leaving it alone when a man goes up. Kline came at a trot that would cost him at eleven, running like a man who had learned to run toward because running away had always made him easy to hate. He did not look for Claire because he knew if he did he would find her and he could not afford to have two problems in the same air.

Claire was already there because if she could smell rain, she could smell the place where a story decided to finish itself. She came in her mother’s shoes and set her canvas bag down at the foot of the ladder like an apology and then collected it because she did not need apologies today. She wrapped the chain around her forearm and stood where the metal leg of the tower met concrete, an edge that was an edge, and she put her mouth to it and spoke his name in the way you have to speak if you want your sound to ask the thing you touch to carry it farther than you could on your own. The leg took her voice and played with it like a tuning fork testing a tabletop. The rain heard her say Alessandro and turned it into static, and up on the catwalk the man stopped without making an admission of having been stopped.

He set the bag where the catwalk curves and the line would intersect the round if you were the kind of person who drew lines on photographs with pencils. He wedged it with the conduit and taped it with the tenderness he saved for objects and never for bodies. The array had a mouth, and he set that mouth toward the town he planned to make his instrument. He flicked the switch with his nail as if nails were made for electricity and not for turnings of earth. The sound it made was not sound. It was suggestion. It was the way a room suggests people should sit, the way a church suggests hands should fold, the way a courthouse step suggests speeches are not acts but obligations, the way a father’s belt suggests certain jokes are not jokes anymore. It ran along the ribs of the tower and into the ground and under the courthouse and along the clay lip of the creek and into bright kitchens and dull rooms and out through the open window at Harv’s shop and made the string on the clothespins tremble like new foals.

The bells in the church couldn’t find which way to fall and then did fall in a pattern you could only call a tantrum, and it was magnificent. The roofing tin rattled and warred with itself, not becoming music, refusing. The band kids beat trash cans and the trash cans remembered their first assignments in the world and did it badly on purpose. The train on the far side of town held its note too long with a willful pride no machine ought to own and then chopped it like a cheap saw and no one in the cab smiled, though later they would, alone, in their kitchen chairs. The tower stiffened like a thing affronted by insult. The array pushed and the town pushed back. It was not a draw because draw is a neutral word and nothing about this was neutral. It was a fight where neither party could touch the other’s skin and made do with the things that had.

He lifted the camera not because he needed it but because he had taught every other part of himself to be disciplined and the camera was the one part he allowed to be disobedient. He pointed it at the town in general because this was not about face anymore and then he brought it back down toward specificity because he had seen, below, the one mouth that would not be fixed to his frame. Claire had stepped out from the leg and into the open and her face was the kind of brave that has a tremble under it that makes it generous instead of crazy. He wanted to take that tremble from her. He wanted to own the before and the after. He wanted to prove that if you capture the mouth, the rest of the body will remember its place.

He knew her voice would rise through the tower before he heard it in his ear, and he turned to meet it as a man turns to meet a lover who is leaving. She did not say his name this time. She said we and she said it as if it belonged to her as much as it had ever belonged to anyone. “We are the noise we keep,” she said, into the rust and the rain and the metal with its own memory. “We are the hinge. We are the ugly note. We are the clapping wrong at the end of what was supposed to be your song. We are the pothole nobody filled and the metronome pushed off a porch and the dinner party where the story is told too soon and makes the room believe it is a room without a guest,” she said, and he despised her because she made a sentence and then made it more than a sentence, she made it into a wall.

Kline started up the ladder because sometimes it is a policeman’s job to be exactly where he ought not to be. He found the missing rung by history and not by eyes and made the wider step that would cost him in a knee later and didn’t care. Rain lifted the smell of the tower’s old paint into his nose and made him young again and more tired than he had been at nineteen. He went slow because the tower did not belong to him and because the man above him had patience and men with patience can turn speed into a liability.

Leah had brought her class to her living room because the school had been released early and because parents had looked at her in the parking lot with the same naked question: what now. They clapped wrong at the television when the weather man pointed at the county and said words that had been emptied by use and filled by need. They clapped wrong at the cat and the cat tolerated it with the resignation of saints. They clapped wrong at the phone when it buzzed and ignored it when it would not stop, and then Leah picked it up and said, “We,” and the line went dead as if a wire somewhere had been cut by a thought.

He adjusted the angle of the array on the catwalk because a man who has found his enemy will always blame angle for why the enemy still breathes. He did not look down. He did not look up. He looked at the part of the town that resisted him and hated it and loved it in the way a man hates and loves the brother he cannot stop measuring himself against. He told himself that what he was doing would be remembered as a kind of art with a mean mouth because art with a mean mouth is the only kind the world respects without permission. The tower treated his sound like a rumor and passed it on badly, and every time it did he ratcheted the bag a fraction, the delicate, obsessive adjustments of a man who has never had a hobby that didn’t draw blood.

Claire looped the chain through the ladders’ lowest rung and made it kiss the metal leg in a way that would produce a small stubborn disharmonic every time the wind decided to speak. It was petty and it was effective. She tied the clothesline to the chain and made a web that would carry her insult higher, patient as laundry. She tapped the pot lid with the back of a spoon the way she had once demanded a dinner she did not want in order to make her mother laugh, and the tower learned to hate tin where before it had been indifferent. She did every wrong thing she could as beautifully as she could manage and then uglier, because ugly is stronger if you treat it right.

The rain came harder. It made the catwalk into a proof, a thing that says this is true of all catwalks, and the man took careful steps in his soaked boots because he was not a fool; he was only foolish in his devotion to an idea that made other people’s lungs his business. Kline reached the curve and saw the bag and felt the way his heart tried to match its pulse to the hum it was making and refused. He went to his knees because he was tired of ruining pants being the difference between a man living and a man not, and he put his hand on the wet tape because touching is a friend of victory in a way distance never will be. He did not yet pull because men who pull without knowing what is on the other end sometimes destroy a thing they can’t make again. He spoke to the bag as if it had registers that needed polite greeting. “You had a day,” he said. “You are done now.”

Al turned and saw him and the look they exchanged was one of those long arguments men have at stoplights with their chins. There was no bravado left in either of them, just work and a little disgust at the way their bodies had made them into the men they were. He lifted the camera because muscle memory is faster than hate and quicker than law. He aimed not at Claire and not at Kline but at the ladder itself, and he clicked, and the square came out and he held it between finger and thumb and the rain doilied its surface in wavering white. He watched as if the face of an answer might lift up out of the milk and tell him who he was and what he should do next and it did not, it showed him the rungs of a ladder and the shape a man’s spaces between will make if you draw them.

Lightning hit a mile away and the thunder made the city shiver and the array tried to take the thunder into its mouth and failed because thunder is a god with its own doctrine. The bag hummed and said, in its way, I have done my part. Kline made his choice and tore with his hands and with his heart and the tape gave like a conception and the bag shifted and the conduit bit the catwalk rail and prayed to stay and then did not and slid and struck his shin and made him say a word you only say to a man you love or a machine that has almost taken your hand. The bag swung and hit the angle iron and bounced and then was less sure of its position in this world and then it fell and the sound it made on the way down was one long embarrassed vowels you could have translated if you had been inclined to be generous.

It hit the ground and died like a toy beyond repair. The tower shuddered in relief the way a body does eventually when you stop pressing a bruise. The air remembered it could be air again and not instruction, and it stood up straighter and then it slumped because storms take their tithe. The rain exaggerated and then gave back the exaggeration with interest. One of the band kids, miles away, felt suddenly better and did not know why and put it down to finishing a scale without missing the note he always missed.

Al stared at the space where his bag had been like a man looking at the plot of ground where he had planned to build a thing that would impress himself. He did not roar. He did not even close his fist. He recalculated with a speed that should have impressed anyone paying attention. He stepped toward Kline in a way that was neither threatening nor friendly but looked like the footnote to those words and Kline met him with the open hand that said later, I had no choice but that lie is always available. They balanced on a catwalk that had opinions about weight and the rain wrote a long sentence on their shoulders the way rain will when it has been asked to be theater and has agreed reluctantly.

Claire stood below in her ugly shoes and had the thought you have to inventory before you can hate it properly: if he falls he will crush me and he will break me and if he does the town will remember me kindly and that is not how I want to be remembered. She stepped out of the way of that thought and put her body under a different idea. She stepped toward the ladder as if encouraging it to be the center of all things and she spoke, not to the men, but to the metal. She said, “Hold,” and the tower, which did not care about English or the way it makes promises, did anyway.

He lifted the camera again not to shoot but because he did not know what else to do with that hand. He had spent years making it a friend and now the friend could not help him. He looked down at the square in his other palm and the rain had obliterated its argument. It was a blank with a memory of having once considered an image. It looked like a thought that had been interrupted in the doorway and had been too shy to come in. He held it like a dead moth.

“You don’t have to finish,” Claire shouted up, and it was not a trick sentence. It was a mercy she wasn’t sure she had a right to offer. “You can leave the lip open. You can refuse the circle. You can let us be ugly and you can say you had enough of clean. You can be the man who stops a sentence because he has remembered that the period is not a mercy if what it ends is still breathing.”

“You don’t get to be my we,” he said, and his voice came down the tower as a flattened thing, but she understood it anyway and flinched as a person does when a word hits a bruise from a previous word. He took a step back on the catwalk because he wanted to see her face and he wanted to make sure his foot knew the pattern of the metal for next time and he wanted to be a person making choices and not a person being taught and that was when the ladder shook in a way that belonged to old hardware and not to men.

Kline reached without thinking and had a hand on the man’s sleeve and the geometry of it was bad. Weight shifted toward a number no one had planned on. The catwalk wanted to let go of something and couldn’t decide whether it would be its bolt or his wrist or the rain that made it sick. They hung like a question mark carved out of meat and intention. Claire felt their gravity reach through her shoes and into the ground and she wanted to scream but screaming is a frequency easy to count and she had taught her mouth to hate being counted in this last week and so she laughed, ugly and unmusical and wrong, a scrape you would not record and play for friends later, and the sound was so poor the tower did not know where to put it and chose to put it down. The catwalk remembered that it was metal and therefore obedient under certain circumstances and one of those circumstances had arrived and passed. It held.

They stood, the three of them, separated by ladder and rain, bound by the physics of a town that had decided to be alive. None of it was beautiful and all of it was true. He looked down at his hand, the one Kline had had to touch in order to keep him on the right side of the vocabulary of death, and he did not pull away. He did not reach back. He held still in the way that says I will make a choice later when you are not watching and let us both pretend. Kline, who had been a man long enough to understand the value of pretending, did not force the moment to declare itself. He took his hand back and let it hang by his side and the feeling in it was a throb he would not admit to anyone.

The rain thinned like a promise. The clouds ran out of speeches. The tower smelled like something you would keep in a garage and apologize to. He lifted the camera to his face at last and then did a radical thing for him: he lowered it without taking a picture. He slid it into the pillowcase and tied the knot with a tenderness that implied marriage and death. He walked the catwalk to the ladder without haste and when his boot hit the rung that wasn’t there he made the wide step like a man born in this town and then he made the rest of the descent a sentence with commas, steady and annoying. He stepped onto the ground and the ground accepted him because ground does not have a politics beyond gravity.

People had come without organizing themselves and they left without applauding. Mrs. Landrum’s dog had decided to be brave and had peed on Kline’s tire in an act of solidarity that the dog could not explain and none of them wanted to interrogate. A boy on a bike had watched from the next street and would tell the story later in a way that made him the hinge and nobody would begrudge him that because being a hinge is a kind of work. Leah walked up with a child on each hand and a third clinging to her sleeve and she nodded at Claire in a way that said she was paying with interest on a debt that was good to owe.

He did not run and he did not submit. He walked into a ditch like a man who believes ditches were made by men exactly like him and therefore are owed to him. He moved along the edges the way he always had. The town did not follow him because it had learned that following is a music and he loves music too much. They watched him lessen and they did not make a plan because they were plan-tired, all of them. Kline let him go because sometimes what you let do not tells everyone else it can be done and this was not that day. He did something instead that felt exactly like his father unlocking the hardware store in the morning and flipping the sign and sweeping the front walk—the ritual that says we exist again after a night. He turned to Claire and said, “We put a man at the shed,” and she nodded, “and a woman,” she added, and he pretended he had said that part first.

Evening came with a sweetness that felt undeserved and they took it because taking good things without argument is the reward for the rare correct day. Harv nailed a piece of tin to the back of his studio door with a single nail at the top so that it would sigh when someone entered. The doughnut shop ran out of coffee and refused to brew more because the owner had learned that scarcity makes a room quiet and he was opposed to it. The old man with the harmonica took it out on his porch and played nothing in particular and people walking by felt their bodies make adjustments they would not name.

In the shed, which had been visited by men with gloves and a woman with a camera who made photographs that did not stay in their squares but roamed, the line of Polaroids shivered on its string and then held still, as if to acknowledge that there are rooms where likeness has to wait for meaning. One clothespin sprang and did not break and a photograph slid an inch and settled. It was the one of the church lipstick, the crooked red, the human effort visible where it usually attempts to hide. Claire stood in the doorway with the state man and with Kline and with Leah, who had come because she had supervised enough art projects to have earned the right to stand in rooms where images get made. They looked at the mouths and did not say the word mouth. They listened to the rain finish making its point on the tin roof. They began, without telling each other, to think about the day after this one, and the day after that, and they did not yet call it hope because hope is a clean word and the day was not clean. They called it clear, and that was a word the town had always been able to love.

He slept and did not. He lay on his cot and listened to the insects call to one another in a language he did not make and could not control, and it made him incandescent with a grief he would never permit himself to name. He dreamed that he had closed the circle and the town had obeyed and he had walked through it like a preacher through a murmur and then something had happened to the quiet, it had failed to be his friend, it had become merely an absence and not an instrument, and he had woken with the word unfinished in his mouth and the taste of tin in his teeth. He swore to the ceiling the way a man swears at a horse that spooks at a shadow he cannot see, and the ceiling had learned to ignore him.

Morning took up its chores. The sky did not apologize. Children ate cereal with small percussions in bowls. The train made its promises to the crossings and kept them. The water tower, clean and factual, held its body.

And in the alley where the town’s new words had appeared on brick, another hand had added a line, thinner than the rest and careful in a way that made you want to scold it and hug it both. WE ARE THE NOISE WE KEEP, it said, and beneath, AND THE QUIET WE CHOOSE, and under that, smaller still, NOT THE QUIET WE ARE MADE. People passing nodded as if the brick had spoken a greeting and they were too well mannered to leave it unanswered. A woman stopped and ran her finger over the chalked letters and found, to her surprise, that they did not come off on her skin. The rain had set them. The town had decided to keep this one. It would not be wiped away with the week.

Kline brought to Claire a sandwich he had not made and did not claim had been made for her. He set it on her porch and sat and admitted by the position of his hands that he had used them today for things that did not require force and had been grateful. They did not talk about plans because plans had been their diet and they wanted fruit. They spoke of Leah’s student who had demanded to be allowed to write a report on the physics of wrong clapping, of the boy from the fence who had asked if he could keep the rope that had burned him because he did not want it to burn anybody else and then had accepted a compromise and kept a length of clothesline instead, of Harv’s wife who had told Harv to stop granting evil so much craft and to come to bed.

“He isn’t finished,” Kline said finally, not to bring the air down so much as to keep it from getting above itself.

“He thinks finishing is owning,” Claire said. “He thinks the circle is a deed. But there are mouths that never close. There are mouths you can’t finish. There are stories that refuse to end even when the last sentence looks like a period. He hasn’t met those yet and I don’t know if we are the people to introduce him or if he will find them anyway.”

Kline stretched his legs and his old knee spoke in a language he would be fluent in soon whether he liked it or not. “We got time,” he said, and the word we did not feel like theft when he said it. It felt like a hand on a porch rail and a dog asleep in the daytime and a woman stringing clothespins on a line. It felt like a sound that did not need to apologize for itself or explain how it learned to be ugly.

He stood and picked up the paper from her porch and put it under the leg of her table out of habit because that is what you do when you see a wobble and you can fix it without a committee. The table steadied as if to say, this is all the engineering I require. He tipped his hat which he did not wear except when the world asked him to act the part of the man his daddy had taught him to admire. He said, “We’ll be stupid again tomorrow if we have to,” and she said, “I’m counting on it,” and they left the porch having believed each other.

At the edge of town, where the ditch elected to be a creek again and the trees made a vote for shade, a man taller than sense paused to look at water that would never be his. He put his hand out and felt the air on his palm the way boys hold their hand to a wind out a car window and teach themselves what a wing is. He said a word that might have been we and might have been no and then he left the word behind on the lip of the bank like a coin balanced on the edge of flipping, and the creek, tactful and ruthless, took it and turned it over twice and did not report the answer. The day had work left. The noise was in the keeping. The quiet would be chosen or it would not. The town continued. The map wrinkled. The circle waited, open like a surprise that might be mercy and might be simply unclosed.

The night carried a hush so low it seemed the pines themselves were listening. A thousand needles leaned in, and the frogs along the ditch went still in a single inhalation of fear or awe. Under a bruised moon, an enormous man waded through waist-high grass as if he were crossing a dream, heavy and slow and sure. The boy behind the hurricane fence had climbed a stack of cinderblocks to see what made the ground thud like a heartbeat, and he kept his breath shallow the way his grandmother had taught him when the hounds ran close. Be quiet, the boy thought. Be a leaf. Be a knot in wood.

Something moved beyond the field’s edge—the silhouette of a billboard for cigarettes long discontinued, a metal mouth rusted into a grin. And then the figure was there under it, a piece cut out of the night. Big, the boy’s mind whispered. Big is not the word. The air thinned around him, shrank away. There was a halo of fireflies hanging in astonishment, and when they scattered the boy could see hands like slabs of stone and a face most shadow, least expression, until it turned. The giant looked toward the fence as though he had been listening to the boy think. The boy’s heart went sideways. A rabbit darted and tripped the wire, and the fence gave a small voice, a little zing—the kind of sound you’d only hear if you were waiting for it.

Between the giant’s fingers, something flashed. A camera, square and old. A click like a lid closing, and another; a tiny throat of light from the body of the machine. Even at the distance, the boy knew it was an instant. Someone his age had shaken a picture like that before, held it at the edge as a face surfaced from gray. This one would not hold a face. It would hold a mouth. The boy had read about it the way you read about storms that happen in other states, sure of your safety until you are not.

The giant placed the photograph on the small of the billboard’s metal leg and walked on. He had a patient stride, a metronome steady, and with each step the ground admitted he was there. The boy did not move. He wanted to call out to anyone, everyone, to the frogs even, to say he had seen the shadow in the field, the man like a moving obelisk, but the sound died in his throat as if his voice understood what his body did not: that sound would be noticed, weighed, measured, judged. The giant passed into the curtain of trees without breaking a branch.

Later, the boy would climb down, circle out brave, his hands prickling with nettled leaves. He would stand before the photograph under the billboard. He would see a mouth, soft and close, the lips pressed together as if to keep in a secret. The mouth was not smiling. The mouth was alone. He would not touch the little square. He would run and run and tell, words jamming against his teeth like fish wanting back to water. He would be believed, and he would not. In a town where belief and disbelief braided like river strands, both true and untrue at once.

At a lit table in Atlanta two days later, Doctor Winston smiled for the camera with a practiced heart. The museum had copper sconces and a grant, a leather smell of old money and newer books. She was reading from her latest, The Speaking Earth: Folklore and the Language We Live In, answering questions about accents and how words come to us like inheritable hair. Someone asked about silence, and she answered the way you answer when you’ve written twelve chapters and still feel you know almost nothing. “Silence,” she said, “isn’t empty. It’s as full as a concealed river. In the South, we’ve made furniture out of it. We lean on it. We think it’s part of the house, but it’s a guest, and it has its own mind.”

After, people lined up. A woman with a magnolia pinned in her hair said her grandmother used to salt words, let them cure. An undergrad asked for a selfie, then changed her mind, then changed it back, the way fish do with light. Claire Winston—she was Claire to herself and Doctor to others; make of that what you will—signed her name the way her mother had taught her, with a second flourish to make it look like a thought trailing off rather than a goodbye. That was when the text came in, a number she didn’t recognize, Meridian area code.

You need to come home. The words were not theirs. They didn’t apologize for the hour. They didn’t say please.

She found a corner and called back. The man who picked up had a voice like a boot in gravel. “Doctor Winston,” he said, as though he had practiced to sound like someone from television. “This is Sheriff Kline. I don’t suppose you remember me.”

“I remember your father’s hardware store,” she said. “I remember the bucket of nails by the register.”

“That’s him,” Kline said, with a laugh that broke in the middle. “Five-gallon bucket. Ten different gauge. One scoop and you’d get a surprise.” He cleared his throat. Milked the pause. “We got something we need you to look at.”

“I’m not a detective,” she said. The standard defense. Old habit.

“Didn’t say you were. You know how stories plant their feet. We had a—something left at the edge of a field. Boy saw it, told his folks, they called us. It’s a picture.” He was quiet a moment, the air on the line stretching thin. “It’s… I don’t want to say this while you’re not here. There’s a way folks tell things when they’ve seen, and a way when they haven’t. You come see. Please.”

The please had arrived. It was new. She lingered with the phone against her ear after he hung up, the dead line warm on her skin. She looked out the foyer windows at the museum’s pond, a flat coin of water surrounded by ornamental grasses. A couple stood near the bench with a paper bag of pastries. They leaned toward each other; their mouths made a small oval of laughter. The parts of us that invented language were, she’d always believed, born from the desire to move thought across a gap and into a listening ear. The anatomy of that wish was a mouth, a hand, an ear, a shared look, and—beneath—the ache to be known. She held her own mouth shut till she tasted copper at the seam and didn’t know whether the taste was memory, fear, or the ends of words burning through.

She drove back the next morning, four hours of road that fell away in a gray ribbon, truncated by storm and summer. Eighteen waking hearts of her life had been spent leaving Meridian, and nineteen returning; her father used to say that was the math of being born where people think the trees themselves tell tales. “They do,” she’d say, and he’d laugh and say, “See, you already proved me wrong.”

By late afternoon, she was in a town that had never decided whether it was awake or half-asleep. The murals on empty storefronts were new, the three-footed Art Deco building was old, the doughnut shop was the same because it would be the last thing to die. Sheriff Kline’s office still had the framed aerial map with a crack through the glass over Bonita Lakes, as if a miniature earthquake had been contained in the frame. He was thinner than she remembered and looked like he’d spent his youth chewing bark. He shook her hand with both of his, an old habit powered by simple manners or fear, she couldn’t tell.

“We didn’t bring it here,” he said. “Didn’t want to bring it through town any more than we had to. Thought you’d better see it in place.”

“You think the place matters.”

“I have a feeling about that,” he said. “And I think you do too, if your book is to be believed.”

“Books are true and untrue at once,” she said.

He grabbed his hat. “You notice how folks always quote your writing to you right before asking you to do something you don’t want to do?”

She thought of all the times her own words had walked in ahead of her like children tugging at a stranger’s sleeve. She followed him anyway.

At the field, the grass had a habit of shining even in shadow. The chain-link fence held a scrap of shirt where someone had climbed too fast. The billboard hunched over the ditch, advertising nothing to no one, the aluminum peeling like fish scales. Sheriff Kline led her to a leg of the signpost. There, taped with clear packing tape, was a Polaroid as crisp as a seen thing. A mouth. Lips relaxed, closed. The upper lip was slightly fuller, and if she had to say anything about it she would have said the person’s face just beyond the borders was young, and she wished she did not have to be the one to say it.

“Photography like that,” Kline said, using the word like that as if it were a species. “We got three in two months. One in Vancleave. One down near De Kalb. All at edges—roads that turn into dirt, you know the type. Always high enough to be deliberate. Always sealed. No prints we could pull. No nothing.”

“And the child?” She kept her voice in that narrow place between clinical and kind, a tightrope only a certain number of sentences could walk.

“Missing since yesterday. Eleven. His mama hasn’t stopped breathing in, if you know what I mean.”

“I know,” she said, and she did. She had been in rooms where the air had a shape made by grief and no one wanted to step through it for fear of breaking it, a glass bowl full of bees.

She didn’t touch the picture. She bent closer, reading the edges the way she’d learned to read stories. The white border had a thumb-smudge. The emulsion had a smart little leap in its surface, as if a bubble had tried to rise when it was drying. Tiny as a freckle of rain on a hot car top. “Old film,” she said.

“You can tell.”

“They stopped making this stock years back. People still buy old packs. Sometimes they store them wrong. The colors go funny. This one didn’t. Whoever’s doing this knows something about temperature and patience.”

“Temperature and patience,” Kline said, tasting it for clues. “Sounds like cooking or killing.”

She looked at him and didn’t say anything. The words hung there anyway.

They walked the field’s perimeter. There wasn’t much to see. There never is, when someone wants there not to be. At the fence line, a boy in a Braves T-shirt stood with his mother, who kept a hand on his shoulder like she meant to hold him there till college. The boy looked at Claire with solemn concentration. He had seen something and put his eyes around it to try to make it smaller. She nodded to him, and he nodded back like a little governor.

On the way back, Kline said, “You grew up with Pastor Pruitt’s lot, didn’t you? You know his daughter. She teaches third grade now, over at King Road.”

“Leah,” she said. “We ate our first peaches together. We built a raft that sank in ten seconds. We thought that was a triumph.”

“She’s one of the ones who called about the last photograph. She’s been organizing the parents, keeping the kids off the trails after school. She’ll want to talk to you. She thinks you might have a way of telling the town what this is so we can have a way of putting our hands around it. You know how to do that, they say.”

“I know how to take a story apart and put it back together,” Claire said. “That is not the same thing as catching a man.”

“Maybe it is if the man is made of story,” Kline said, surprising her, then shrugging, embarrassed by his own reach.

He left her at the courthouse steps with the promise of dinner in paper bags later. She walked to the square where the bankers took their lunches and the pigeons wore their suits. She thought about mouths. Her mind had always turned to anatomy when frightened, the way a heart returns to rhythm after a startle by enumerating its parts. Lips, labial, labrum: the rim of a barrel, the edge of speech. The mouth was the border between the inside and the weather. On the way back to her car, she passed the window of the photography studio that had been there since the seventies. The man who ran it now kept his father’s sign and his father’s ways. He was in the back, repairing something with an eyeglass magnifier. He looked up and raised a hand. She walked in without quite deciding.

“Doctor Winston,” he said, knowing her the way towns do, by accumulation. “I read that one you wrote about train whistles once. That bit about the music nobody asked for.”

“Harv,” she said. “You still keep old film in a cooler?”

“I do. I told my wife, if the house burns, I’m taking the cooler out first.” He smiled, then read her. “What do you need?”

“How many people around here would know how to keep vintage Polaroid stock alive through a summer?”

“Half the teens online think they do,” Harv said, “but they don’t. They like the mistakes. They like the streaks and misfires. The kind of picture you’re thinking of, somebody’s determined. They’re in love with the clean miracle of it. I sell to a club of men who meet once a month to talk about the good old days. Couple new kids. A teacher from the community college. That kid from the newspaper. And—” He paused, let the thought rest in his mouth like a seed he could either spit out or swallow. “We had a fellow come through with hands like they were built to hold lumber. Not from here. Asked questions. Didn’t buy anything.”

“How long ago.”

“A week. Maybe two.”

“What did he ask.”

“He wanted to know what to do if the film made the colors wrong. Asked if a cooler would keep it right. He had this way of hunching when he spoke. Like he had to make himself smaller to fit in the room.”

“Did he give a name?” Her voice made the question a feather, as if it could slip past him and collect dust without stirring.

“Al. Said friends called him Al. That’s nothing. Everyone’s called Al if you look at them right.”

“Tall,” she said, because saying giant in Harv’s tidy shop felt like exposing something indecent. “Big.”

“Like a church,” Harv said quietly. “He made my ceiling look lower than it is. Even when he sat.” He pointed with his chin toward the door as if the man’s height might have bent the doorframe’s memory. “He stared at my mouth when I spoke. You ever have that happen? People look at eyes, or they look away. He watched my mouth. I didn’t know what to do with my tongue.”

“Did he buy anything,” she said, knowing he hadn’t.

Harv’s eyes darkened. “He took a picture on his way out. Asked if he could test the shutter on an old Land Camera I hadn’t priced yet, lifted it without meaning to ask, like it belonged to him. It had film in it. He shot it not at anything. Just lifted it and clicked like a reflection was enough. Handed it back and left. I didn’t notice till after that it was a picture of—” He stopped.

“Of what,” she said.

He went to the back, touched a drawer he didn’t want to open, opened it. He came out with a square in his palm. He showed it to her like he was showing her a bruise. Her mouth. The picture was of his wife’s mouth in a frame on the counter. Harv had forgotten the frame was there—a wedding picture. Lips made soft by the memory of a vow. The square captured only the lips, and the bit of chin, nothing else alive or showing. He had placed the photograph face-down in the drawer.

She swallowed. “You kept it.”

“It felt like evidence,” Harv said, ashamed of the word. “I couldn’t throw it away the same way I can’t throw away the last button from a shirt if I know the shirt got lost and not worn out. It’s wrong, but it’s mine.”

“Let me take it,” she said. “Let me give it to Kline.”

He hesitated, then handed it to her with a slight bow as if she were the kind of person who took such offerings away, cleaned them, absolved them. She slipped the photograph into the inside pocket of her jacket. It lay against her chest, cool against her shirt, as if it had a temperature all its own.

On her porch, later, Meridian dusk made everything louder: the insects, a train throat-clearing three blocks away, the tinny voice of a baseball game from her neighbor’s stoop. Leah walked up the steps with the old familiarity of a girl used to walking in uninvited. She had the same braid she’d had in sixth grade, just made wiser. She hugged and let go at just the right time. They sat.

“You remember how you used to tell stories until my father said if you didn’t finish before the biscuits were ready he’d have to throw a towel over your head,” Leah said.

“I still don’t know what that meant,” Claire said.

“He’d have done it,” Leah said fondly. “We need your stories. Not the old ones. The new ones that tell the old ones. Something’s happening and we’re making rules with our mouths because we don’t know what else to do. We’ll sing in the school gym so loud he can’t hear us, someone said. And I said, he doesn’t want to hear us. That’s the point.”

“The mouth as a door,” Claire said. “People always think closing it keeps them in. Sometimes it just makes it easier for the wrong person to press a finger to the latch.”

Leah’s hand drifted to her own lips. “I keep telling the kids their voices are good. That their names are a form of armor. You think that matters?”

“It matters,” Claire said. “But armor can also make a target.”

Leah looked out at the oak across the street, its branches thrown wide like a question. “Sheriff Kline says this man’s got a plan. Says he’s not just wandering. Someone who walks like that,” she said, meaning the rumor that had reached the town before the formal words did—someone whose steps made windows remember. “What would he want.”

“To be heard in a way that makes silence,” Claire said. “The maxim is old. Air loves equal pressure. Sound hates it. If you make enough of one, you erase the other.”

Leah chewed that. “He called me,” she said suddenly, shocking herself. “Before the second picture. He didn’t say anything. He breathed. I knew it was him. How do we know things like that, Claire? He breathed and my heart counted every breath like it could make him stop if it kept up.”

“You tell Kline that.” Claire heard the sharper note in her own voice. “You don’t keep that. You give it over.”

“I didn’t want to make it real,” Leah said, small. “But it’s already real. I’ll tell.”

Claire walked the blocks of her childhood that night the way one revisits a dream to look for something missed. The mills were quiet. The dome of the courthouse sighed itself into the sky. She passed the playground where she had once fallen and cut her lip on the corner of the slide. Her mother had bent to her, put her own mouth over the cut as if she could pull the pain out through the skin. The memory lit with a fidelity she hadn’t asked for. It made her stop on an empty sidewalk and hold her mouth together like two pieces of a broken plate.

He was a half-mile away, stepping through the swamp’s lip of cattails, moving without hurry toward the truss bridge that cut the river like a scar. Alessandro. He had been given that name in the first fever of his parents’ hope, and in time he had pruned it down to Al to fit in the places where the ceiling was low. He was not from Meridian, but he was from its cousin, and a cousin will recognize a cousin even when they’ve tried to change their hair and their state lines. He measured distance by what he could cross in an hour and measured people by how loud he imagined their ancestors stood under the sun and shouted. He had learned hate the way some men learn carpentry: you can build a chair, you can build a gallows, the hands don’t pause to ask which.

The first time he had taken a picture of lips, it had been an accident, and it had felt, for one terrible clean instant, like invention. A woman at the bus station had laughed at someone behind him. He had turned and hit the shutter without knowing why. When the developing finished and the picture made a square world, those lips emerged like an animal in its winter den.
