It had felt like catching his own breath in his fist. He didn’t think in words often—they scuffed his brain like grit in gear grease—but he thought in shapes, in the geometry of openings. A mouth was an opening. A mouth made sound, and sound had made him run from rooms as a child, belly burning. He had learned to make quiet with his hands. Now he made quiet by collecting the shapes that made noise. In the shed in the disused lot where he slept, there were sheets of photographs clothes-pinned in a neat, precise line. They were his hymnals. He did not read music. He understood arrangement.

He remembered the store man and the way the store man’s mouth had made nervous ovals and moved like a small fish in a jar. He had loved the way the man stopped moving his tongue as if the tongue belonged to him and the man was immaterial. He had managed not to laugh. Laughter was for people who had mountains left to climb. He had a plan, and a plan consumed laughter like a fire consumes oxygen. It was too soon to say, even in his own head. It was never too soon not to say it out loud. He didn’t say things out loud when they mattered. His father had told him, a long time before the world learned how tall he was, that anything said out loud could be held in another man’s hand. This is mine, he thought, and walked on, and listened to the bridge tremble as if it had remembered something.

At dawn, Claire sat in the library archives with a pair of white gloves making her own hands unfamiliar to her. The towns around Meridian kept their own clip files; hers were no exception. She wasn’t looking for him. She was looking for the phrase he had stepped out of. Monsters don’t come from air; they step out of the vocabulary we swear we don’t use anymore. She found a story in a 1911 Meridian Star about a man who had walked from the lumber camps to scare the townspeople with his height; she found a photograph from 1962 showing a woman holding a sign that begged someone to listen; she found a sentence from a church bulletin that asked people to close their mouths for a day to honor the dead. She circled the sentence and copied it into her notebook without knowing why.

“Doctor Winston,” said a voice. Leah again, holding a Styrofoam cup of coffee. “You were always a morning person,” Leah said, a little accusatory, as if morning itself were an opinion. “Kline’s asking for you for a minute.” She put the cup down in a crescent of papers and winced. “Don’t yell at me for the ring.”

Claire smiled. “There are worse marks than coffee on paper.” She closed the file gently.

Kline had a room in the station he’d converted into an idea room. It had a whiteboard that had known better days and a bulletin board that had known bullets. Pictures were pinned in a neat spider’s web. Not the Polaroids. He was saving those for a more sterile gaze. These were locations, dates, missing posters, a map with pushpins.

“He keeps to the edges,” Kline said, tapping the pins. “He puts them high, like he wants us to look up. He doesn’t want us to find them by accident. He wants us to find them just slow enough that he knows where we are. You see how these lines make a thing,” he said suddenly. “I don’t know what it is yet. But it’s a thing.”

“It’s a circle,” Claire said. “Almost. He’s tracing, with the edges. Closing it by inches. Some people think if you finish the prayer just right, it comes true. Some people think if you measure the town with your feet, you own it. I think he’s measuring to make a shape he wants to fill.” She didn’t say the word. She didn’t want it to learn she had one for it.

Kline rubbed the bridge of his nose with his thumb and forefinger as if he could rub away what he had seen. “We also got this,” he said then, reluctant. He had a small evidence bag. Inside, a postcard. It bore a picture of a quiet lake. On the back, in a careful hand: The world is too loud. He had written it in a neat schoolboy script that made Claire’s skin rise. She felt her mouth. She didn’t touch it. She could not help imagining the hand that had held the pen; something so deliberate in that body felt obscene.

“Handwriting analysis,” he said. He had already sent it.

“You won’t get him with that,” she said, and it sounded cruel, and she was sorry, and she was not. “He’s not someone who thinks he has to write to be known. He thinks he can push noise out of a room by walking through it. He will want us to come to him the way a song comes to a chorus. He already knows where we stand.”

She went home on foot, because the air was the kind that could not move faster than a walk and be believed. A card was tucked in her doorjamb on the outside. It had no stamp. Inside, someone had drawn a mouth with a child’s red pencil—the roughest curve of lips, almost comic. The words below were blocky, almost gentle, almost apology, almost prayer. Your words make more mouths. She put the card on the kitchen table, and her elbows on either side of it, and rested her forehead against her knuckles. He had walked up to her house like it was an errand. He had stood under her soffit where the wasps were trying to decide if the season had ended. He had looked at her door and decided she was not home. He had not guessed her car. He had not guessed her habit of walking. He had not looked up at the kitchen window and seen her face. He had looked only at the seam, at where one thing became another. She understood something then about him that she hadn’t before: he saw the world as a series of edges. He misunderstood that the center was where light collected best.

She held the card a long while and then gave it to Kline and watched his face change the way faces do when what is private becomes a civic matter. He cursed, very soft. He said, “He can’t be let to decide what our words are.”

At night, when the sound of her neighbor’s game ebbed, when the tree frogs took the air back for their own, when the train cut through the belly of the town and made its long throat-clearing more announcement than apology, Claire lay awake on her back like a patient under old lights. She thought of the boy at the fence. She thought of her own mother, who had once told her there was no such thing as a man taller than a story. She thought of how wrong and how right that was. She pictured a man walking into a room where children were singing and raising his hands not in blessing but in calculation. She pictured him laying out his photographs like an atlas. She pictured silence rolling across a floor like a tide. She turned on her side and pressed her lips together, and listened to her own breath as if it were someone else’s and she could learn how to stop it or encourage it as needed.

By morning, a rumor had raced around town that he had been seen near the rail yards, stepping along the center line of the tracks like a balance beam that only he could carry. Claire went there with her notebook, because she could not not go. The yards had the smell of iron and rain. A cat watched from a pile of pine. A man in a yellow vest told her she couldn’t be there and then, when he recognized her from a picture in the paper from five years back, told her she could as long as she didn’t get herself killed. “That’s the rule,” he said cheerfully. “Stands for everybody.”

She walked along the far fence, felt the shiver of something larger. Not an engine. Something else. The sound of walking, but slower, clockwork. She looked up. The trestle cut the sky into squares. On it, for an instant, a figure. He paused, one foot ahead, a stillness like a held note. Her jaw went cold. She knew the measure of him before her eyes had the detail; the way the world under him reacted told her what her eyes needed to know. He looked down. He could not possibly have seen her face at that distance. He saw the way a mouth moves even from far away.

“You,” he said.

She did not know that she had said anything, but something in her must have formed. The word left her without her consent. “Alessandro.” It was what was on his birth certificate, and if she could build a bridge to him it would be built out of the first name someone once chose with care, not the one he had chosen for himself when he decided to hide. She hated herself for it. She clutched it like a tool and prayed it was not also a gift.

He tilted his head as if he had heard a chord resolve. “That’s not what anyone here calls me.”

“Your father did,” she said, because she had read the census with its household names and because it sounded possible. The truth did not matter as much as the shape of the truth; it was a key; the door would either fit it or not.

He smiled, and it was terrible. Not because he bared his teeth. He didn’t. He did not show his mouth at all. The smile was in the way his cheekbones made the air step back. He lifted his hand and made a small square between his fingers, and she felt her lips wanting to perform for him, to make the shape he could capture. She held them still. It was a muscle more than an impulse. She made herself plain.

“You should go home,” he said conversationally, like a man leaning at an outdoor table in good weather. “You should write your book.”

“I am home,” she said, and he considered that as if it were a variation on a theme he hadn’t expected. Then he moved on, the trestle murmuring under him. He walked out of her frame. It was as if a ceiling had fallen and then been caught again without a sound breaking.

She called Kline with hands that did not feel like hers. She gave him everything except the part where she had said his name like she had been given it to keep. She kept that thing and put it on the shelf where she kept the glass she had used to catch hornets with when she was ten. Useless, dangerous, a trophy. She didn’t know if it would help or hurt, later, to admit that she had called him that. She only knew her mouth still felt as if it had been looked at too long.

The giant’s shed was a place without clocks. Time in there was counted by how fast the chemicals breathed. He hung the latest square by a clothespin and made himself not look at it. He had learned discipline the hard way, the way you learn to carry water without spilling in a pan across a field—by slopping it two dozen times and being told to lick it up. If he let his eyes move over the pictures in a certain way, he could hear a kind of music; he could hear what he thought of as relief. He would not indulge. He had a plan that was bigger than relief. He cleaned the lens. He imagined the gymnasium down by the school as a mouth. He imagined it shut.

He thought of the woman at the tracks who had called him a name he hadn’t earned. He had no feeling about her beyond irritation that she had bent the air in a way he hadn’t chosen. He had a few words. He kept them in his pocket like a knife. He would use them once and fold them again. He did not say them now. He slipped the small camera into a pillowcase and tied it like bread for a journey.

In the evening, Leah came to Claire’s porch with the news that the PTA had moved the fall festival into the gym, that the children would sing their songs early to be home by dark. “You’ll come?” Leah asked, and Claire said yes because saying no would be like building a door in a house with no walls. The sky had pulled itself low and purple. Someone had already hung lights. The gym had that smell of floor wax and lemon and centuries of breath.

The children lined up, ridiculous and magnificent, and moved their mouths around words about stars and corn. Claire stood beside Kline at the back. She wanted to shield them with her hands like eggs in a carton. Kline’s jaw worked. “We pulled cars round the back,” he said, too casually. “We don’t advertise our fear. We don’t not feel it.”

She nodded. She looked at the EXIT signs as if they were talismans. She counted. She made a list in her head of who she could carry if she had to. She watched the doors. She could not not imagine him. She could not not imagine the sound of his step. The giant did not come. He did not come. She did not exhale. Somewhere between verse and chorus, she felt an odd calm. It was not safety. It was the opposite. It was the knowledge that he was waiting for a note they hadn’t hit yet.

When the children finished, the room spilled its applause like a bucket and everyone’s mouth opened at once and the space expanded by inches because sound makes space. Claire watched the fact of it. She pressed her lips together, then let them fall apart, then brought them together again. It felt like the oldest decision in the world. It felt like a door with a stubborn latch. She left her mouth open, halfway. A compromise with air.

At home, there was a letter under her doormat. No postcard and no drawing, just a sheet of paper torn from a lined notebook. He had written two sentences, and if letters could whisper, these did. The world is too loud, he wrote again. Tomorrow, we make it quiet. The we was large and small at once, presumptuous and inclusive. She folded the paper and cried in a way she did not like to be witnessed, soundless, the body’s way of letting something pass through it like weather. Then she did what she had avoided doing since she’d stepped into the field with Kline. She called her sister in Baton Rouge and told her something she had not told anyone except Leah once in an unimportant afternoon when they were seventeen. “I dreamed once,” she said to the phone, “that I could not speak and no one noticed. It was the best dream I ever had. And then I woke up terrified. You cannot make a life between those two things without a crack.”

“You always did like a crack,” her sister said, aiming for light and landing near.

“Not this one,” Claire said. “Not this.”

The next day drew itself up hot and blinding as if the sun were overcompensating for all that hush. Claire drove past the school. The gym was locked and proud. Sheriff cars hunkered at each corner like dogs. Claire parked two streets away and walked. Her shadow could not keep up. She had the piece of paper from the doormat in her pocket like a shard of ice. She stopped to buy a bottle of water from a church youth group and a brownie wrapped in saran that stuck to itself no matter which way you peeled.

At noon, when the bell rang and the sound came like a flock of birds out of a roof, she looked up and saw the trestle, the line of sky above it, the possibility of a figure slowing there to look down and measure. She looked at the mouth of the gym, hinged and simple. She looked at the mouths of the children spilling out into a hungry day. She looked at her own reflection in the library window across the street—her mouth an idea, then a fact.

She heard, once, a step. It might have been a truck hitting a pothole. It might have been the beginning of the hour. She made herself walk toward the place where the sound had pointed. She knew she could not keep this man from making his shape. She could only interrupt, interfere, speak into it, make it stutter. She could make him look at her mouth instead of anyone else’s. It was a terrible thought and a good one.

She did not see him right away. He did not want to be seen, not yet. He was already in the space where he had rehearsed his silence. He had measured the doors and learned their particular songs. He had a thing in his hand that did not look like a weapon. It looked like a joke. It looked like something someone brings to a picnic to make children laugh. He would not be a man who loved laughter, but he could use its shape. He placed it on the floor near the bleachers where the air might carry a surprise faster; he stood and stepped backward, measured again, listened as the room told him the endings of himself.

Claire saw him then. She did, and he saw her, and both their mouths performed the only shape available to them: the opening that is not a word. She felt the three inches between them expand to take on the mass of everyone who had ever asked her to turn a story into a rope and throw it to them. She opened her mouth and said his name. Not the one he wanted. Not the one the town had fed into the rumor mill. The old name. The first best one. Alessandro. It left her throat like a sob and a verdict at once.

He flinched in the smallest way, as if someone had dropped a note of music into a room where he had been counting in his head.

Behind him, Kline came into the door like a man in a story who had decided to be late only once. He had his hands open, visible, a courtesy in a place like this. It made everything slower. It made nothing safer. The room did not know yet what it was about to hold. The sound had not made its choice. The giant was taller than the moment, taller than the town, taller than the story she had brought up from the page like a bucket from a well. He smiled without smiling. He lifted his hand. He had a teacher’s patience. He would instruct the room in the art of not speaking. The children’s laughter rose from somewhere like an accidental choir. Claire stepped forward. Her mouth remembered the first instrument it ever was. She drew a breath that would have to be enough. She spoke as if sound could be armor. She spoke as if stories could change the weight of a man’s hand. She spoke his name again. The room turned toward her like a sunflower toward a brief, wrong sun. She spoke again, and again, and felt her own words become a wall someone else could lean against for one more unbroken second.

He didn’t look at Kline. He looked at her the way a hawk looks at a rabbit hole, measuring not the animal but the opening it might use. His hand hovered above the thing he had set by the bleachers. It was foolish-looking the way a clown’s flower is foolish until it spits acid in a joke no one wanted. A cooler, red and white, with a hinged lid and a faded sticker of a baseball team long gone to a different city. Someone had written FAMILY on the side in permanent marker as if labeling might keep a thing kind. She’d seen coolers like it under tailgates and beside baptism ponds, sweating cold and condensation into gravel. There was a cord under it that winked out like the foot of a snake, and the plug found a friendly strip by the scorer’s table where someone had left juice for microphones that would carry small voices into a crowded place and make them large.

He pressed the little black bud in his palm and the air pushed its shoulders up without moving. The room heard a sound that wasn’t a sound; a pressure like a figured sum laid on the chest; a correction; a suggestion that the inside should meet the outside and make a treaty. The children’s clapping went ragged and then stopped, like minnows ceasing at a shadow. You could feel the breath of the gym find a different direction to go. Smiles slid away not because of fear but because smiles are a kind of sound and the room had forgot the word for it. There was a half-second when the very old wood of the floor remembered riverbed; it bucked underfoot without rising.

Claire did not think. Thinking belonged to rooms where the pressure was polite. She moved past Leah, who had stepped into the aisle without knowing she’d done it, and reached for the fire alarm because it was near and red and everyone in the South had been taught since birth to distrust red that hangs on a wall. Her hand paused on the rectangle, the way a hunting dog pauses when told for the first time he might grab a thing and make it his. If she pulled it, she would make noise and panic. If she did not, she would help a man flatten a room. Her mouth found the sound first. “Clap,” she said, uselessly, and then found the shape of what she meant. “Wrong,” she said, much louder, pushing the word out like a chair into a closing door. “Clap wrong. Stomp wrong. Off the beat, baby. Don’t count. Make a mess.”

Leah understood quicker than Kline did. She leapt to the edge of the lowest bleacher and windmilled her arms the way a choir director does when the choir has decided to be heaven without instruction. “You heard her,” she said, and the children looked at her because they were always looking at an adult to see which way the day was tipping. “Don’t listen. Don’t match. Do it all wrong. Make the loud that doesn’t add up.” She laughed in an ugly way on purpose, a scrape of sound you couldn’t harmonize to save your life. The thing in the cooler was hungry for sameness. It synced to sameness like a parasite. It hated the slop of a barn band.

The nearest boy—Braves shirt, the fence boy with the old eyes—slapped his thighs deliberately out of time. He made noise like a drawer of spoons dropped on a tile floor. Someone beside him tried to copy and failed and that failure was exactly what the room wanted. The gym took a breath. The pressure met edges and broke like river on rock. Claire yanked the alarm then anyway, because she trusted herself to love contradictions, and the klaxon bellowed a dinosaur sound that made the device shrug, fail to anticipate, try to cancel a frequency and, because the horn modulated and lied about being steady, miss. The noise was unbearable in the way breath is unbearable when you’ve been underwater too long; it hurt and it was the right hurt.

Kline went low and quick in a way that made you remember ribboned track meets and football practice in a life before paperwork. He had the face of a man who would apologize later for touching someone’s property, and a foot that did not pause. He hit the cooler with a kick that he would feel in his hip at midnight. The lid sprang and then half-closed, then sprang again, and she saw inside a nest of ugly speakers bolted into the plastic with a patience that was a talent. There were weights to keep the box where you put it, small amplifier guts like a heart pulled from a chest. Kline tucked his hands under the thing like it was a pig at a roast and counted, one-two, with his mind, and pitched. A deputy who had been born to catch caught, and together they crabbed it toward the exit, every third step a stumble because the air does not like to let something go it has been shaping. When they got it into the open hallway, the difference was immediate; sound rushed back as if it had been waiting in the vending machines.

Al did not move at first, and that was his mistake. He had expected panic. He had counted on panic. He had not counted on ugliness. He had not counted on a town choosing to be unmusical in public. He had never learned what to do with people who loved their mistakes like pets. There was a sliver of time when Claire could see him revise his beliefs, and in that sliver she knew him for what he was, which was not a god and not a monster but a man who had grown strong carrying an idea bigger than him and had mistaken the weight for virtue.

He lifted the camera that had slept in the pillowcase like bread, and the cloth fell away like a dropped handkerchief at a race. The thing was not old in the old way; it was an old model made to look chic again, married to a patience for batteries. He aimed without raising it to his eye, a shooter who had taught his arms to be eyes. That was when Claire made the ugliest shape she could with her mouth. She did not mean a face to frighten children; she meant a refusal. She let her lower lip hang like a broken hinge. She flapped her tongue like a child being cruel to another child. She refused to be a border. She refused to be a neat rim that held something back or let it out. She saw the flash be itself. She felt the small animal of light crawl across her teeth and away.

“Don’t,” Leah said to him with a teacher’s permanent hope that the word might still have purchase among the currently disobedient. It hit his chest and slid off. He had a second click ready in the muscles. Kline shouted and it wasn’t a law word; it was a name he had found on an old booking sheet and promised himself he would use only if he had to make a man hear his mother again. “Alessandro,” he shouted, and it did what Claire’s had done and what it would always do if someone said it right; it cut the air in the shape of the old kitchen his father had built, the one with the too-low ceiling and the flat smell of a sacrificed life.

He took a step back that wasn’t a retreat. It was a measuring step, recalibrating how many strides it would take to leave and how many to stay. The room had found itself. Children were crying and laughing at once; a principal was counting heads with the speed of a casino dealer; a deputy was patting thin shoulders with too-large hands, trying to be many places. The fire alarm insisted on a lesson. The infrasound had fled into the hall with the cooler and died of cold. Claire could feel her heartbeat again up in her mouth where words live.

He could have kept on then. He could have done the worse thing. He did not. He slid the pillowcase back over the camera because he loved cleanliness; he loved clean beginnings and clean ends. He turned and walked the way a man walks when there are eyes and he won’t give them a run. It made his height larger. He did not hurry. He did not touch a child. He passed a row of paper turkeys children had made from their hands, each with five painted feathers, and the thumbs were all too big because children mismeasure themselves. The cutouts fluttered with the wake of his passage and did not fall.

Claire followed and did not know she had until the exit door slapped against her shoulder and made the bone smart. Outside, the air had a carnation pinned to it: crisp and showy. Sirens were trying to find the right street, always two turns slow because a town knows its own shortcuts better than a man in a car from the county. He angled not for the road, where hands and rules live, but for the strip of planted crape myrtles that led to the maintenance gate and then the back of the kitchen where the dumpsters stood pronouncing their own names. She had a foolish thought that he would not fit where he wanted to go. He did. The world had been building doors for him his whole life. He walked through another.

“Don’t chase,” Kline said to her shoulder, and his breath fogged and made a temporary ghost. “Please,” he added, practicing for a world where please might arrive early instead of late. Then he went after the man because telling someone not to chase and not chasing yourself is a recipe for being someone you don’t like in your own head. He looked, in that small second, exactly like his father had looked in the hardware store when someone tried to walk out with a handsaw under a coat. Politeness first. Then a hand on the elbow that was firmer than instruction.

Claire did not run. Her running would have been a gesture and she had run enough in her life to know when her running was a ritual. She walked into the sunlight with her mouth wasting a breath for every thought and let the important air go to the men who needed it to move their legs fast. Leah shepherded children with the pained, tender efficiency of someone who had birthed something with her voice and had to get it out of the dumbest river. The alarm cut off as if ashamed and the sudden vacancy made everything tender to touch. You could hear a shoe squeak. You could hear a child say, “My ears,” like a complaint to God.

He was not there to be caught behind the kitchen. He had learned more about exits than any room could teach. The door to the supply alley was jimmied in a way that would not show unless you knew how a hinge looks when it has been asked too much. He had left nothing, which is not the same as leaving no trace. There was a small triangle of paper on the asphalt where a hand had fumbled, torn, and not known. Claire bent without meaning to and picked it up. It was the corner of a photograph, the white border cut on the diagonal, the emulsion missing the thing that would have given it intent. It was an empty mouth. It was a frame inside a frame. She held it like a tooth and wanted to spit.

The deputies fanned, radios shedding words that meant comfort to the men holding them and static to everyone else. Kline came back with his own mouth a hard line. He did not look at her because he was gathering himself into a shape he would need to be ten minutes from now. “We did a thing,” he said, and it sounded more like a question than a boast. “We kept it from being the thing it wanted to be.”

“You made it messy,” she said, and realized she was shaking and could not find the place where shaking began. “That’s the only way some machines can’t count you.”

He nodded, and the nod acknowledged a debt he had no pocket for. He glanced at Leah, who gave him a teacher’s report—two children left early, four headaches, one nosebleed, nine who would need a snack and a nap—and he looked grateful for numbers because numbers make a fence around bad. Then he pointed with his chin at the cooler. It sat in the hall like a prop that had been caught in the wrong act. “We get this to somebody who can look at it and not see a lunch,” he said. “We’ll see if the state boys have a man who knows speakers from bombs.”

“Harv will,” Claire said, before she could talk herself out of dragging him deeper. “He’ll know how a thing was made if it breathes electricity. He’ll know which catalogs the screws came from. He’ll know who likes to order in bulk and pay in cash. He’ll know the smell.”

Kline rubbed the heel of his hand along his jaw. “And he’ll be in the middle and that is where I don’t want people I know,” he said. “But here we are. Bring him to the station. Don’t give him the box. Let him bring his magnifier to us.”

She nodded and stepped out of the path of a flood of grandparents who had heard a siren and knew their grandchildren were made of breakable parts. The street outside had filled as if a parade had been promised. People looked at each other with the naked eyes of a town that had shared a scare and would share a story and would call it something with a name that could be laid on a table without embarrassing anyone. She saw a woman touch her mouth and then double that touch with the same hand as if she hadn’t got enough the first time. The crape myrtles knocked their knuckles together in an indifferent breeze.

By late afternoon the gym had been surveyed into statements. The cooler had gone to a room with a locked door. Leah sat on Claire’s porch in the clothes she had put on the morning of a normal day and cradled a lukewarm bottle of something fizzy she would not drink. She had the look of someone who had used all her grace and now had to borrow. “They sang like they were going to break the roof,” she said, and a flush of pride made her face look ten years old. “I told them I didn’t care about tune and a few of them looked at me like I had given them permission to walk on the good carpet.”

“You did,” Claire said. “You gave them the trick every old woman knows in her body. When the pot boils, stick your spoon in and make a mess. The mess is part of the recipe. It’s not written on the card because the card was written by a woman who thought husbands didn’t like to think about the kitchen being work.”

Leah laughed and then put the heel of her hand to her mouth to hold in the sound as if the sound were something someone might steal. “He took your picture,” she said, because not saying it would not make it untrue.

“He did,” Claire said, and felt the cool spot on her skin where the flash had sat. “He won’t get what he wanted. Not today. I gave him the wrong shape to keep.” She realized with a small grief that she had spared herself and given him another woman’s mouth years ago without knowing—Harv’s wife. The shame moved in a circle and came back to sit beside her like a cat, uncalled and unavoidable.

Harv arrived at dusk with his eyeglass in his pocket and a nervous smile that skipped a gear when it changed. He looked at the cooler with a craftsman’s dread the way a man looks at a cracked vase his grandmother loved. “This is fine-print evil,” he said, not to be poetic and not to be heard, but because naming is a habit his father had beat into him in the shop behind the portrait studio. “I can take it apart without killing whatever you need alive.”

“I need the story of it,” Kline said. “Not the brand names. The why. How a man with patience put himself on the floor under elementary school feet.”

Harv had gloves and put them on without looking down. He lifted the lid like an apology and touched the wires like they were snakes he knew by family name. He talked as he looked. “He made an array. Cheap speakers in a drum will do something; this is speakers in a patience. He nested. He damped his own casing with carpet. He weighted the corners to keep specifics. He had to test this somewhere with a big room. An empty one. He had to be a janitor or a thief.” He reached in and eased a screw with the tenderness of a dentist. “The sound isn’t about loud. It’s about under. Low enough it makes your molecules talk to each other about quitting. Any simpleton can make a bleed-your-ears box. This is a cough in the lungs of a building. You ever set a tuning fork on a tabletop and felt the wood say thank you? That’s this, rude and multiplied. If I had to say, I’d say he didn’t buy these speakers new. He pulled them out of things. Cars. Aerobics rooms. There’s adhesive here that isn’t factory. There’s sawdust in the grill that came from a place with old wood. He built in a shed.”

“A disused lot,” Claire said, and felt her throat click on a remembered clause. “Clothes-pins,” she added, useless as always and sometimes necessary. “He pins his pictures the way his grandmother pinned laundry. There’s a line in that house if there was a house. There’s a line in the shed if it’s a shed. He likes neat. He likes neat evil. He thinks neat makes it less evil and more clever.”

Harv found a signature in the weld in the way a coyote finds a rabbit without seeing it. He leaned. “See that ripple. Someone did this with a home kit and nerves. He didn’t sleep the night he glued. He stared at the seam and decided it was good because it was small. He had to borrow a heat gun. He can’t afford a shop. He has a friend or a person he hovers near and takes what he needs from without making a ripple.”

“We look for garages with missing things,” Kline said, and a deputy wrote it down like a prayer. “We look for sheds with new locks in old walls. We look for men who get hives in crowds and hold their breath when the choir sings. We look for someone who has made himself a room he believes is the whole world.”

Harv nodded and then had a thought that made his mouth go small. “I should tell you I have a hole in my film cooler,” he said to Claire like a man arriving late and out of breath to a confession. “The kind that happens when someone reaches and doesn’t lift before the ice has had time to melt. I patched it. I didn’t tell my wife because she loved that ragged blue thing. But I should tell you. I thought it was nothing at the time. A drop-in. A glance. A hand that didn’t take anything because hands sometimes don’t. The hole was in December. He was here before he was here.”

“Everyone is,” Leah said, not unkindly. “That’s how stories work.”

The paper worked itself overnight into the shape of a lesson. The Meridian Star ran an extra that talked about quick action and public safety and brave children and didn’t use the word the town was using to itself at kitchen tables where the sugar canister lived: mouth-man. The broadcast from the Jackson station did something else; it said a new word like it had been waiting to say it: quiet-bomber. People repeated it then and dragged it like a crate to other places until it left grooves. A woman in line at the Piggly Wiggly said she always knew the gym’s floor was soft and this proved it. A man at the barber said a little quiet might not kill anyone, and the barber cut his ear on purpose and pretended not to, because some statements need blood on them to be whole.

Claire dreamed that night the way people dream after a building has asked their bodies to listen to a frequency they were not built for. She dreamed she was teeth in a jar, dentures in her grandmother’s glass on a tiled counter, and the glass was rattling with a bus passing and the bus was full of mouths going on somewhere to be arranged. She woke with her own teeth clenched so tight it took a minute to decide whether they belonged to the dream or to her. She got up and put water in the kettle and then remembered she didn’t drink tea and put the water in a glass and let it sit in her mouth the way old men hold whiskey when they mean to think.

A car idled outside in the way cars idle when they don’t want to admit they’re idling. It had patience. It had a low niece of that infrasound but not enough to be a cousin. She went to the window in her bare feet like a person in a story who has not yet learned what happens to people in stories who go to windows in their bare feet. The street had the look of three in the morning and a cat crossed it like a rumor. The idling stopped as if it had finished an argument with itself. She went to the door later and found a thing any teenager could have made if he had been bored and wicked: a piece of cardboard with a circle cut out of it, taped to a stick. You could hold it and look at someone and make their mouth be the only thing you saw. It was greasy where fingers had held it and there was a line of pencil on the circle’s edge where someone had practiced making the opening smaller and larger, deciding what was the size of a person’s voice exactly. She took it inside and held it to her own face and looked in a mirror because she believed in doing the thing all the way. She saw her mouth alone and felt in her chest the awful thought a person only has once: that she could be reduced and at the same time still be herself and be asked to live that way.

At first light, she walked to the swamp path because the sun coming up over a body of water will sit a woman down and make her shut up the way a schoolteacher does. There were men there already who never slept and talked with their backs. The cattails put up their brown thumbs and the lilies pretended to be placed by a hand. There were tracks that were not deer and not man, big as the map of a hand. An egret lifted and wrote its white cursive across the pond and made mercy into a thing with wings. She stood long enough to collect her weather into something carryable, and when she turned to go, he was there at the bend, not his body but the way the air had after a tall man has walked through it and left the lint of his shape. She knew he had used this path as a drawing pencil. He had made the town lean in on its own edges to see what he meant.

Back at the station, Kline had gone from coffee to water and back again to coffee because coffee was a shovel and water a towel and he needed both to move what he needed moved. He had lines on his map that resembled ribs. He had placed the locations of the photographs and the edges and the attempted quiet and the seen and the seen-not-seen in a circle that was not a circle, shy of closure by two inches that were not on paper but in rain and knees and luck. He tapped the map with a pen he chewed like a boy, left a tooth in the plastic, and finally admitted the shape that the pins were trying to tell him without being rude about it. It was a mouth. It was the shape of a mouth, traced off the city limits, edged in fields and trestles and hallways. It had a lower lip fattened by the river. It had an upper lip torn by a road project from 1989 that no one had forgiven. He had been told in school that a circle was the simplest shape and the perfect one. He had never been taught how a mouth is a broken circle that keeps a person alive.

“Tell me I’m making patterns where there are none,” he said to Claire when she came in, leaning on the doorframe like a woman who had gone to the swamp because the only god she believed in lived in mud. “Tell me I’m looking at a loaf of bread and calling it a Bible.”

“You’re looking at a mouth,” she said, and did not enjoy saying a sentence that would sound in a week like something a woman says in a podcast from far away. “He is writing a sentence you can’t hear. He thinks when he closes the shape the sentence will read. He thinks the room will obey if all the lines meet. He would have completed the lip at the gym. He would have taught us to be his word. He’ll try again. Soon. You will not get to him with cars. You will get to him with corners.”

“Corners,” he said, as if the word had left him a tip. “He likes edges.”

“He thinks the center makes agreements it shouldn’t,” she said. “He thinks edges are pure. So you put a person he cannot ignore where two edges meet. You make a junction that bothers him. You put right where a wrong wants to live and let them argue.”

He stared at her as if she had given him a riddle that was also a map and also a dare. Then he laughed the way a man laughs when he is so tired his face will only go one way and it happens to be the one that hurts less. “You know what my daddy used to say about you when you were ten and wrote letters to the paper about trains being mean to the night?” he said. “He’d say, she’s going to grow up to be a person the town puts to work and doesn’t pay. And he was right. And I am sorry. And thank you. And do you see why I don’t have a dog. I can’t be responsible for anything that looks at me like that every morning.”

She smiled and didn’t and went to the window because the window was where she understood what scale was. In the square, a man had set up a folding table with a handmade sign that said BRING YOUR NOISE and was selling kazoos in colors that hurt. Children bought them with dimes and parent permission and walked away and made indignities in public. An old woman bought a set of marbles and taught three small boys how to let them fall on concrete to make a sound like hail in a tin roof. A boy had a cowbell and no sense of when to ring it and the best timing in the world. In a week this would be tiresome and in a month it would be a story that made people blush. Today it was armor. Today it was a bunch of edges refusing to be tidy.

The next picture arrived where it would. On the inside of a church door, high enough you had to get the step-ladder people used to twist Christmas wreaths to reach it. It was a mouth again, but the mouth had lipstick on it that was crooked, a woman’s I did my best at red. The note had nothing on it except a single drawn line, and the line had a dip in it, and the dip was the truth. It was the dip in the upper lip some people had and some did not and he had made a mark of it as if to say, I can see the small things too. Pastor Pruitt took it down and held it and held it and then put it in a Bible because men like him think anything put in a Bible becomes tinder-proof.

Harv looked at that one and said he could smell on the emulsion that the film pack had been opened in heat and then shut and then cooled and that the person who did it did not sweat as much as he should. “Some men don’t sweat,” he said, and shook his head. “I don’t trust men who don’t sweat. Even Jesus sweat. Even the devil.”

At night, Leah’s phone rang again and the caller didn’t speak again and she spoke first, because that is a trick that belongs to women who have had to learn to be brave on a page. “You’re not the only person who knows how to breathe,” she said into the mouth of the phone, and then she laughed in his ear ugly and wrong and made him hang up because he didn’t have a box for that and didn’t like his boxes to be handmade.

Al walked the abandoned spur line that ran behind the old cotton compress and measured where the moonlight avoided him. He had added the gym to his line in his head and been interrupted and hated the way breaks looked in patterns. He had arranged his pieces in the shed until they matched a picture in his mind that was a sound as much as a map. He had liked the way the room had gone quiet and hated the way it had gotten itself back like a fish he had had in his hand and lost in the grass. He had re-laced his boots tighter because his feet were too big for the laces, but the act of tightening them made him feel he had caused a smaller order. He imagined the mouth closed and the town shut and the river laid down its rattle and the birds forgot to sing and the trains remembered that someone had been here before them who did not need their announcement. He thought the word we again and tried to decide whether he liked it. It was a heavy word. He liked heavy words that you could hang things on. He didn’t like Claire holding his name the way she had. He would fix that. He had plans for what people could and could not say, and her saying the wrong thing had been a splinter he would tongue until it bled.

You could see where this was going if you let yourself. You could feel the jaw of the town locating its hinge. Sheriff Kline made his cars sit at corners like bookends. The school district adjusted bells until the pattern was not tidy. The doughnut shop gave away free coffee to anyone who promised to slurp and provided plastic lids with holes too big. The courthouse clock went on the fritz and no one tried to fix it for a day because it made an interesting erratic song. A high-school band slept with their instruments and practiced in the Parking Lot of Bad Decisions behind the bowling alley until the notes went wrong and right and wrong again and that was better than right. Parents who never yelled in public stood on porches and told the dark they would not be made smaller in their own mouths. It sounded corny and felt like remembering how to breathe after being startled awake.

In the hours between three and four when the body loses most of what it borrowed from the day, Claire lay on her back and stared at the ceiling where cracks had daintily been made to look purposeful and wondered what it would be like if he succeeded. She tried the thought on as if it were a shirt someone had left behind at the pool. A quiet that was not a peace but a power. A quiet that made every prayer sound like it must be whispered to be good. A quiet that made all stories ground down to their bare bones and the marrow sucked out. She hated that kind of quiet with a bone-depth hate that surprised her. She had lived her life loving hush and this thing wasn’t that. She got up and went to her desk and turned on a lamp and wrote a sentence she had been resisting and it felt like a bandage; it felt like a fight. She wrote: In the beginning was the noise, and the noise was with us, and the noise was us, and we did not know it until someone tried to take it. Then she wrote: In the beginning was breath, and the breath had edges, and the edges were where we learned who we were allowed to be.

In the morning she read what she had done and didn’t hate it and hated that she didn’t hate it and printed it anyway because some words need to be made into paper to be heavier. She took the page to Kline and he took it like a man takes a thing that is both bullhorn and lullaby and asked if he could put pieces of it on the county website and she said yes and he did, and somewhere a woman who had never thought the internet could make her safer read it and put her hand to her chest and said a name out loud she hadn’t said in a long time and the shape of the name made that day bearable.

By noon, the rumor river had decided he’d be at the Rivoli, the old movie house that made promises in the twenties and concessions in the nineties and was now a church for a congregation that liked its music tinny and insistent. It was a bad rumor and a good thought; inside, the acoustics would be a bowl he’d hold like soup. Kline went anyway and found nothing but hymnals with brittle spines and a scrap of tape on the stage where someone had once marked center and then decided to be off it. He stood a long time in the dim and realized he had come to love the backs of rooms. He loved the backs because backs let you see people without being seen. He had grown up in a hardware store looking at the backs of men picking nails and thought that was what law would be—helping backs hold right. He had been wrong and was learning even now how to be right in a different way.

Toward evening, when the air went wet and the trees put their hands on their hips, a school bus driver called it in: a man taller than sense walking along the ditch by the far edges of King Road where the asphalt becomes confession. The driver had three kids left, going home to houses where a light outside made a kind of statement, and she did not stop because you do not stop for men in ditches even when the men are not giant, but she said to the radio what she saw and then she sang loudly with the children on purpose, Row, Row, Row, and told them to be wrong on the word merrily, and they were, and they loved her for letting them. Kline was three minutes behind a cloud you could watch grow. He parked angled without meaning to and put his hand on the roof of the cruiser because his daddy had taught him cars had souls and deserved a pat.

Claire was already there because a woman from the PTA had called Leah and Leah had called her and the string of calls had made a braid that meant action. She stood at the fence that hemmed a pasture with cows who had opinions about nothing and everything and saw him in profile, a cut paper hero in some wrong parade. He looked at the fence the way a man looks at a line he could step over and not be forgiven and then he didn’t step over because he had rules, he had his own shames. He lifted the camera like a sacrament. He made the small square with his fingers before the square plastic could honor it. He was going to take a mouth out of the air like a coin out of a child’s ear.

“Alessandro,” she said, and it was not a tool this time but a hello. He did not like that any better.

He looked at her with the kind of disdain that is only available to people who have kept themselves away from laughter for years at a time. He looked at Kline with the contempt of a man who had measured and found him wanting and then had to adjust his math. He looked past them both to a place none of them could see, and she knew what he was looking at. He was looking at the last pin on a map he had made inside his head out of a woman’s greatest hope and the edges of things that did not belong to him. He was looking at the mouth he would finish.

She lifted her hands without plan and without grace and held her fingers apart in a book of a gesture. “We grew up with a rule,” she said, and was surprised to hear herself go there, to those dining tables and those girls and those warnings. “We were told when the dogs ran not to run. We were told be the tree. We were told be the knot. We were told be the stone. We learned not to be the river. We learned wrong. Rivers are loud and that is why we are alive. Be the river with me, Alessandro,” she said, and the words were not pretty because prettiness is something that doesn’t hold in rain. “Be the river once and see if it kills you.”

He did not lower the camera. He did not raise it, either. He held it at a middle where men hold things they think are both dangerous and salvation. His mouth softened for the first time Claire had ever seen it soften. It made him younger and made him ordinary and made him, in a strange, unpardonable way, beautiful. He opened it and she thought for a second he might give her a word. He did not. He closed it again like a door someone on the other side had tried to open. He turned away, which is something men with rules do when they have not yet decided to break them.

After he was gone again into the trees he did not bend, a thing happened the way it has to in a book even when the town is tired and the writer is tired and the sheriff is thinner than his suit. A woman in a house at the top of the hill where the ditch turns and a pear tree leans had lowered her mouth to a child’s ear and told him a story of a boy who wanted more silence than he could carry, and the child, who had perfect timing because children are timing dressed as people, lifted his kazoo and blew a note so wrong it went right, and the cows lifted their heads, and the sound went out over the field and into the first edge of the wood and back into the ditch like a handkerchief tossed and caught and tossed. You could have called it nothing. You could have called it a seed. You could have called it a beginning the way some people call storms early to scare them away.

Harv took apart the cooler that night while his wife made soup that smelled like commas. He found a scrap of cloth wedged under a weight, a piece of pillowcase torn ragged as if someone’s finger had caught and someone’s patience had been outvoted by someone’s hurry for once. He put it in a Ziploc like a man in a TV show he had never wanted to be and drove it over to Kline who bagged it like a man who had a whole drawer of bags and then said the thing men say when they know they owe you a thing and do not want to owe anyone anything: I’ll remember this. Harv went home and kissed his wife like a first date and said he had touched the edge of a story and not been cut and she said, not today, and it was the most accurate prayer anyone had offered in town.

Whoever was supposed to be keeping the fire in heaven lifted it then, a small, red, velvet corner of a sunset that made an oath it could not keep. Claire sat at her desk and wrote the chapter she had been putting off, the one about silence as furniture, the one about the kind of quiet that is a guest with a knife in his boot. She wrote about mouths without saying the word too many times. She wrote to try to arrange her fear into something that would stack. She wrote, because they would ask her to, the story of what had happened in the gym and she made of it not a brag but a recipe. She wrote: clap wrong. She wrote: break the counted. She wrote: there are men who make maps that hunger. We do not owe maps our bodies. We owe maps our ugly, square, stubborn noise.

At the edges of town, the crickets decided to tune and the frogs took their creek back and the train did its long moan and apologized to no one. In a shed that thought it was a body, pictures hung by clothespins stopped being hymnals and became a calendar. You could feel the day on them even in the dark. He lay on a cot that had more springs than mattress and counted his heartbeat down to a thing he could carry and swore to the ceiling that it would be quiet tomorrow and the ceiling rained plaster like a small studio audience expressing doubt. He didn’t hear it because some men don’t hear the room when the room is disagreeing. He did not sleep long. He did not sleep well. He dreamed of a river he could step across and did not know how to get his foot dry again.

In the morning the field where the boy had first climbed the cinderblocks had a small gathering whether it wanted one or not. People who lived nearby stood with mugs and opinions. A woman from the paper took notes like she was catching butterflies and planning to let them go in a lede later. Claire went alone because she wanted to see what the place looked like after being in a story, and it looked like a place that had not asked to be in one. The billboard still grinned rust. The fence still sang to the wind when asked with a finger. The boy was there with his mother again and he looked at Claire with the sacred solemnity of someone who had made a brave choice and been told it mattered. She knelt so that their mouths were closer to one another and said, “You did right,” in a voice that made it sound like a secret and a proclamation both, and he nodded because children love permission and hate it equally.

On the way back to her car, Claire passed the alley where teenagers painted names at midnight and felt the air change. It was the kind of change that is only a degree and is everything. She looked up and there on the brick in white paint someone had written the oldest line in the book and made it new by facing it the wrong way. WE ARE THE NOISE WE KEEP, it said, and across town Leah read the same four words on a screen because someone had made a photograph and sent it to a friend because that is how air moves now, and Kline read it in the back of his head where officers keep their retired prayers, and Harv thought he might make a sign out of it and put it in the window of the studio, and a man in a shed misread it deliberately to keep from being hurt. He said to himself, I am not we. He said to himself, I am the quiet I make. He said to himself, tomorrow.

The circle on Kline’s map still had a break at the top lip, two inches of unmade. He put his finger there and dared a man he had never met before to try it. He set two cars where streets made right angles and put a deputy at a hardware store his father used to own and a preacher at a skating rink that had been a skating rink when he was a boy and then been a church and then been a tax office and was now empty and looked like a mouth with a missing tooth. He asked Claire if she would do a thing that he had no right to ask, and he put the please in front of it like a word should be, and she said yes because she had been walking toward that yes since the first time she had heard dogs run.

“What,” Leah said, with a teacher’s terror that lives beside a teacher’s joy. “What are you doing.”

“I’m going to stand at a corner,” Claire said. “I’m going to be a knot and a river. I’m going to say his name where two edges meet and see if he knows the difference between an opening and a door.” She smiled then in a way she didn’t like and did anyway because truth lives in ugly smiles as often as it does anywhere. “And you,” she said to Leah, “are going to make parents practice being wrong. You are going to make them clap wrong and tell them the clap is a prayer. You are going to say the stupidest things the Lord ever blessed and you are going to save lives with them.”

Leah put her hand over her mouth and then lowered it and nodded and then laughed and then cried and then laughed again in a sequence that is, if you think about it, the Bible in six seconds. “I can do stupid,” she said. “I am an expert. I have a certificate.”

They put Claire where two streets kissed without privacy. They put her where the railroad cut a crossing and a chain-link fence decided not to be taller. They put her where it was ugly and true at once because ugly and true often share a bench. She stood with a paper in her pocket that said WE ARE THE NOISE WE KEEP in her own hand because she had copied it down because she believes in taking some graffiti home. She stood with a kazoo because someone had given her one and because an old woman had once said to her, take the gifts people give you even if they are shares in foolishness. She stood and waited and let the day measure her and felt the way the town turned toward her with one ear and a half. She could feel him too, out there counting, out there misreading. She had his name and he had her picture and between those two things there was a rope that could be pulled, and one of them was going to pull first. She hoped it would be her. She hoped, if it was him, that she would not go quiet. She put the ridiculous little plastic instrument to her mouth and blew once, wrong. It made a sound like a duck arguing with a door. It was beautiful. It was the beginning of a world where maybe no one had to give up their mouth to live.

Chapter 6

The corner had the shabby theater of a place that had been overlooked on purpose. It was a kissing-point where two narrow streets found each other and then looked away too quickly, a railroad crossing slicing it into tinny quarters, a chain-link fence hemming a utility lot where coils of green hose went to grow old. Claire stood with her shoulder against a light pole that had been patched with a strip of roofing tin and a bolt, and when she leaned she could feel how the two metals disliked each other in a way that was intimate and permanent. Kline’s people had done what they could without making a carnival out of it—two cars half a block away pretending to be shoppers, a volunteer with a stroller and no baby performing the stand-and-visit that keeps a corner feeling used, an older man from the VFW who had been told nothing except that it would be helpful if he brought his harmonica and remembered nothing from the Army except he was allowed to be loud.

Houses around them breathed their weekday breaths. A woman watered the square of grass between her porch steps and the curb as if the square were an animal that might bolt. A boy chalked a hopscotch course in numbers that refused to arrive exactly in order, hopping as he drew with a coordination that argued with itself and won. A man dragged a trash can that had lost a wheel and produced a beat so raggedly satisfying it might have been what a drummer hears in his sleep the night before a show he’s afraid of. Claire kept the kazoo in her pocket not because she thought she would use it but because it was a promise to her own mouth that it was not only for food and apology. She watched the rail, because rails are honest outside of schedules, they tell you with a shimmer before they tell you with a horn, and she watched the fence where the world had the courtesy to declare itself.

The radio in Kline’s cruiser kept up a low gossip of place-names and what-ifs, checks and backtracks and somebody saying sorry for stepping on somebody else’s words. Leah’s text came in like it was leaning against her leg. Kids are home. We’re practicing wrong, it said, and after a beat came a picture: thirty-seven third-graders with their mouths open in wrong shapes, their hands clapped in mischief, Leah at the front with her arms wide like a conductor who had decided to conduct the weather instead. Claire smiled and this time did not stop it with her teeth. Across the street the VFW man cupped his harmonica and let out a line of something that started as hymn and ended as barn dance, a phrase you couldn’t lean on if you tried. He nodded to her, and she nodded back like they were both members of a club that made whatever it needed out of what it had.

Al moved like a set of measurements trying not to be seen. He came along a ditch on the far side of the tracks, keeping his feet in the beaten path that rainwater had negotiated with clay. The day tamped itself down as if preparing for someone to step on it. He had changed nothing about himself except the angle at which he held his shoulders, a small concession to roofs and wires, but even that made the air remember. He had in the bag at his back a device smaller than the gym cooler and meaner, built for corners like this, a quartet of scavenged cones set into a plastic crate that had once held oranges and now held a low lesson. He knew where he would put it. He knew what walls would help him and which would have to be taught. He had thought about this corner after he’d walked it in the early part of the morning when church folks drive without looking and the dew stays on your bootlaces no matter what you do. He had put the line in his head where the map would close and then opened it a finger’s width because he liked to come in sideways on his own plans, the way a carpenter cuts inside the pencil.

He saw her before she saw him because he had taught himself to see mouths from far away and the way she stood made the shape of her lower face distinct against the tired color of the day. He did not say her name in his head because names were for people who had earned them or for people you wanted to injure with the sound. He put her in the part of his mind where tools live. Useful. More useful if obedient. He adjusted the bag’s strap because his hands needed order and because his father had always made him lift with both arms and so he had to be disobedient somewhere. He watched the rail. You watched the rail. The rail will betray a train before a timetable will. He did not mind trains because trains choose their own loud and have an honest horn—four notes, call and answer like a riddle a child figures out by accident. He liked their rules. He did not like what lived under their rules, which was the mess of people.

Kline felt the change before he saw the body that had caused it, one of those policeman things that is more animal than training and which he would deny if asked and then admit on the day he filed the papers to retire. He straightened without deciding to straighten. He put his hand not on his gun but near the place where his belt holds a human still. He flicked two words into the radio because quiet talking is a kind of magic in a small town: on foot. He looked at Claire and found her eyes already on him and did not have to give her the rest—the not yet, the not if you can help it, the please that he was learning movie sheriffs never say and real ones use as a lever.

The man in the ditch gained ground without gaining speed. He had a way of passing space like it was a friend you didn’t hug in public. He set his foot on the rail to cross and the rail made a noise like a struck guitar and the tone was the measure of his weight. Claire felt it in the part of her chest that had learned to read lines of music in church and hated every minute and loved it too. She slid the kazoo out of her pocket and rubbed her thumb along the seam of its plastic mouth, a small sacramental gesture no one saw.

He lifted the crate and tipped it, just enough, to see how the sound would meet the brick backs of the low buildings and the underbelly of the bridge and the fence. It was all edges here; he smiled with the part of him that knew this was a good choice. He could close something at this corner and no one would call it art but it would be art anyway, the kind that makes a room obey. He placed the crate where two cinderblocks had become community by mere proximity, set to make a stand for a plant that never made it out of its black nursery bucket and had died without adding its green to the corner. He turned the knob like you turn the dial on an old radio to find something you know is there because you once loved it at night and it has to be here somewhere in the hiss. He pressed the button. The air put its palm against the room.

Claire had told herself to go first and she did not. The first sound came from the old man with the harmonica, an accident that was also a lesson. He saw the man set a thing down and his mouth made a sound at the same time his hands did; it started as a note and became an objection, the harmonica’s bent reed stamping its small foot in protest. It was the wrong pitch for protest and perfect. The pressure met it and tried to flatten it and couldn’t decide where to put its thumbs. Claire took the kazoo’s insult into her mouth and blew a note that sounded like a goose wising up. She turned her own body into a corner by pivoting and stepping into the angle of the signpost and the light pole and let the air squeeze past her, and in the slipping through the edge lost a little of its rightness, and that was the trick if there was one.

The VFW man caught on fast and wrong, which was what she needed. He took his harmonica off his mouth and smacked his palm with it in a rhythm that refused to keep company with itself. The woman with the watering can banged it against her railing because that was what was in her hand and because this town, for all its failures, had always known what was to hand. A teenager with a skateboard came realized into this corner from the next and laid his deck on its grip and slapped it with a heel, slap-slap-rest-slap-rest-rest in a pattern only he knew and which made the air nervous because it could not make a pattern of him first. Someone in the car behind Kline leaned on a horn and then took their hand off and then pressed again, four times, five times, nothing like trains and that was better here.

Al felt the failure like a man feels the give of a board underneath him and knows to move his foot and knows also that if he stalls he will be thrown. The crate did its work with the dumb fidelity of the built but the corner refused to be taught. He looked not at the noise-makers but at Claire because he had already decided where the hinge was and he did not enjoy being wrong. She looked back at him with a mouth she refused to make into a symbol and he hated the plainness of it more than he had hated anything in a year. He did not lift the camera. He wanted to keep his hands for the thing that would do more. He stepped forward a single step and the world took that step like it had been practicing.

Kline came out of the car like he had never been in one, that clean. He didn’t go for the crate because his foot told him it would be a waste to kick a rope when you need to cut a knot. He went to the man because men are where things start no matter how many machines we build to pretend otherwise. He came to stop two strides off because two strides is where a man has the dignity to choose and you have the dignity to take it away if need be. He set his hand to his side in a way that said I have it and I don’t want to use it and I will. He didn’t speak at him yet and that was the part of himself he did not recognize and liked. He waited in the noise and let it call him a fool and a hero and the father of all wrong children.

The train did a thing then that was strictly scheduling and purely theater. Its horn took the far crossing with the legally required measure—a long, a long, a short, a long—and the shape of it cut the corner open and let the pressure go running the way a bad dog bolts when the gate forgets itself. The crate’s work stumbled and couldn’t find its feet in the new air and by then Claire had come forward to close two human edges around it, her and Kline, a corner of bodies, the thing in the middle forced to listen to a geography that hated it. Al read it as disrespect and that was right and a mistake. He had underestimated how much a small place can want itself and how ugly it is willing to be to keep wanting.

He moved like a man who’s decided that a plan needs brute in it now and reached for the crate to change its angle and Claire did the unglamorous thing and stepped on his cord. It wasn’t bold; it was housewifely, and it worked because electricity loves a certain kind of insult. The plug cocked and the hum went to its knees and in the instant before his hand got to the wire he looked up at her and she said his name, not like a weapon and not like a prayer but like a gate she was holding with both hands from blowing open. “Alessandro,” she said, and the syllables laid themselves across his chest like a wet towel in summer and his lungs hated it and loved it because the body does not get a vote.

He jerked the plug without looking and she was ready for it because most harm is a tug and most resistance is a foot. The teenager with the skateboard had seen men yank cords all his life and had learned the counter and he slid in close and dropped his deck on top of the crate as if he were playing a game only he knew the rules to, and the sudden weight and the dull rubber of the wheels made the thing cancer into quiet. Kline put a hand on the camera not to take it or to break it but to take the aim away from it and felt the man’s hand under the leather not resist so much as refuse to decide. That was the trick in him that was going to get him caught one day—his love of decision until the moment arrived and then his delight in the breath before it.

The horn dragged the air like a comb through a head of hair and everything separated into strands again that you could see. The world looked cheap and friendly as it does after a scare that did not get to be formal. The old man said something like a curse and like a benediction and probably it was both exactly. Al bent in a way that suggested he could take the world apart if he lived long enough and gathered his things not because he had been beaten but because this was not the shape he wanted his failure to be. He looked down at the foot on his cord and then at the kazoo in Claire’s hand and then at Kline’s palm open on the camera and he put his mouth in a shape that people draw when they draw a mouth and have not looked at one in a year. Then he turned and carried his measurements away along the ditch because edge is retreat and attack both if you do it right.

“You good,” Kline said to nobody and everybody, the question-call of a man in charge of a room that has woken up with a bruise. The old man laughed like a rain barrel emptying. The woman with the watering can was crying from the wrists out and desisted only when she found she had set the hose down wrong and it was drowning a patch of the street that could not drown. The skateboard boy picked up his board and looked at the bottom of it as if expecting to see the imprint of the evil he had sat on. Claire breathed like she had paid cash for a breath and had better use it.

A deputy who had been playing shopper came up in a posture that coupled apology and adrenaline, hands out to show he had nothing in them and so much to give. “We got a call from near the compress,” he said to Kline, words sparking off his teeth because speed was not his friend and he knew it. “That old shack. The one with the tin letters still up from the tire place. Somebody says there’s a kid. They heard tapping. They heard it and tapped back and it tapped like a child. I sent Rosales. He says it’s the boy from the fence,” he said, and sounded like he had been given back a thing he had already made a funeral for.

Claire’s throat made the small ugly sound a body makes when someone has removed an anvil you didn’t know was there. The woman with the hose put both hands over her mouth and not because she had been told to. The old man wiped his harmonica on his shirt as if it had sweat, as if it had worked. Kline closed his eyes and leaned on their lids like he had not slept enough and would not for a while longer, then opened them and they were useful again. “You go,” he said to the deputy, “and tell Rosales not to keep the mother outside if he can help it. Let her in if the boy can bear it and tell him it will be ugly and right at the same time, and that is a day’s work. And get the ambulance to come slow. No siren until they are a block away, because he might have had enough of the wrong sound for today.”

They went because nobody had to be told twice to go toward a child they could see now in their head. The corner eased like a jaw unclenching. The train went on and made its commitments to the next crossing down. The crate sat there like a red-eyed dog, hum killed, waiting for a new instruction. Kline squatted by it and peered into its cheap heart. “We’ll let Harv have the throat of this,” he said, half to Claire and half to the object, and the object did not disagree because objects rarely do.

Harv looked at the crate later in the day with a craftsman’s calm that had a sliver of triumph in it because something had been put in his hands that could be undone without hurting anyone else. He ran a finger along the lip where plastic met patience and shook his head with admiration he did not want to own. “He’s learning from himself,” he said. “This is cleaner than the cooler. Less to go wrong. He made it uglier and it improved the trick. He’s got a mind some part of me would hire if the rest of him wasn’t taking up all the space in the room.” He lifted a speaker and tilted it and let the tiny rattle of trapped gravel tell him where the man had stood when he’d put the thing down. “See that? He’s not as careful as he thinks,” he said, and showed Kline the grit in the glue line. “He’s working on dirt. He’s bent over a sill.”

Rosales came in with news that walked like it had been drinking. The boy had been found. The boy had been fed. The boy had been held in a place where holding is a verb that makes your hands hurt later. He had been told to be quiet and had obeyed the way children obey adults who sound like they know what a room is for. He had tapped with a key he’d found under a radiator and had liberally misunderstood the sequence for S-O-S and it had not mattered because misunderstanding is sometimes how you get somewhere fast. He had a rope burn on one wrist and none on the other, which meant the man had taken breaks; he had laid down between his own rules. He had left a cup of water and a half-slice of bread and a small clean towel and a note in a stack of Polaroids that said, Don’t make noise. The boy had made noise anyway and had saved himself by being wrong.

Claire went to the compress lot because she had to see the door jamb where the hinge had been given too much to do and the sheet of tin where He had cut a neat rectangle and then slapped it back so sloppily that anyone who had ever loved neatness with a fierce love would look away. The shed in the back had his breath in it still, a mechanical smell braided with a sweetness she knew from other enclosed rooms—a smell of film, that peculiar vinyl vanilla that people mistake for nostalgia and is in fact chemistry. She stood at the line where the light changed from outside to inside and saw the neat line of Polaroids clipped up like laundry and it made her stomach perform an old circus trick she had retired. There were mouths and there were mouths and there were a few false starts where the edges had bled into the border and those he had not kept. There was the one Harv had found of his wife. There was the one from the billboard leg. There was hers. She knew her mouth anywhere after the last two weeks had taught her to glance at reflective glass and not be surprised by the arrangement of her own face. He had not been content with her unjust ugliness. He had kept the one from the gym and developed it carefully and it was there hanging with the rest, the unhandsome, unbordered refusal. She felt herself split in two neat halves, one that wanted to be sick and one that wanted to stand taller. She did neither. She stood still.

The boy was in an ambulance he did not like because it was too bright and he had spent his bravery budget already. His mother had ridden in the front because the back would have embarrassed both of them and because she had been given a choice and had made it with the little spear of pride that every good mother keeps just to keep from drowning. Leah sat on the curb after and let the concrete tell her she was still heavy. She looked at Claire and the look said three things that couldn’t share a sentence: why do we live like this, I’m glad we do, I want it to end. Claire nodded because nods can hold three things if you make them slow. She would not cry yet, not here, not where crying would feel like making noise for noise’s sake. Later, alone, she would cry and she would put her pillow over her face like a child afraid of the dark and call it a study in suffocation, as if the name could make it friendlier.

That night, the town did what towns do when the weather has lifted and they are not yet convinced it will be kind tomorrow; they went outside. They leaned on fences that had been white once, they let their dogs be unproductive, they talked across distances an arm cannot span, they ate on porches as if porches deserved to be thanked for their years of service. Someone hung a string of mismatched Christmas lights over the square and no one asked who paid the electric. The doughnut shop put a folding table on the sidewalk and stood a crockpot full of something that wasn’t coffee and wasn’t soup on it and the sign said FREE and nobody asked which kind of free.
